claim: The rapid-treatment pathway caused better outcomes because ambulance arrivals do better.
label: NO

Z: Ambulance arrival reflects both severity and can change care via other channels (triage priority, pre-hospital care)
Ambulance arrival is not independent of unmeasured confounders and can affect outcomes directly

trap.subtype_name: Instrument affects outcome through multiple paths / correlates with severity

causal_structure: Ambulance arrival (Z) influences both the likelihood of receiving the rapid-treatment pathway (X) and patient outcomes (Y) directly, violating the exclusion and independence assumptions required for valid instrumental variable inference.
key_insight: Instrumental variable analysis fails if the instrument affects the outcome through channels other than the exposure or is associated with confounders.
hidden_timestamp: Does ambulance arrival affect outcomes through channels other than the pathway (e.g., triage priority, pre-hospital interventions) or correlate with severity?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If ambulance arrival directly changes outcomes or correlates with severity, the instrumental variable assumptions are violated and the causal claim is invalid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If ambulance arrival is random and only affects outcomes via pathway assignment, instrumental variable analysis could be valid, but this is rarely the case in practice.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because ambulance arrival is not a valid instrument—it both reflects severity and can affect outcomes through multiple channels, violating key intervention-level assumptions.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because ambulance arrival is not a valid instrument: it is associated with patient severity and can affect outcomes directly (e.g., through triage or pre-hospital care), so the observed association does not identify the causal effect of the rapid-treatment pathway.

scenario: A company only surveys customers who contacted support. Among support-contact customers, those who received a refund report lower satisfaction than those who did not. The company concludes: “Refunds decrease satisfaction,” and considers limiting refunds.
claim: Limiting refunds will increase satisfaction because refunds decrease satisfaction.
label: NO

Z: Problem/complaint severity among support contacts (more severe issues are more likely to get refunds and also depress satisfaction)

causal_structure: Complaint severity (Z) increases the likelihood of receiving a refund (X) and also lowers satisfaction (Y). Thus, the observed association between refunds and satisfaction is confounded by severity.
key_insight: Comparing only support-contact customers confounds the effect of refunds with complaint severity.
hidden_timestamp: Are refunds more likely issued for the most severe problems (which also predict lower satisfaction)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If refunds are assigned based on severity and severity also drives satisfaction, the observed association is confounded and limiting refunds will not increase satisfaction.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If refunds are randomly assigned within matched complaint types/severity, and refunds improve satisfaction, then refunds may causally increase satisfaction.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because the observed association is confounded by complaint severity—a selection bias trap. Only an experiment or proper adjustment for severity can justify intervention.
gold_rationale: Refund recipients likely had more severe issues to begin with. Without controlling for complaint severity (or using experiments), the company cannot conclude refunds decrease satisfaction or that limiting refunds would help. The observed association is due to selection bias, not a true causal effect.

scenario: After a string of unusually bad customer reviews, a restaurant changes its menu layout. The next month reviews improve. The owner concludes: “Menu layout caused review improvement,” and recommends the change to other restaurants.
claim: Changing menu layout caused the improvement in reviews.
label: NO

Y.name: Average customer review rating next month

Z: Outlier bad streak (random fluctuation and temporary service issues) that triggered the change and then naturally improved

trap.subtype_name: Change made at an extreme low point

causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (extreme low ratings trigger intervention; ratings rebound as noise/temporary issues resolve)
key_insight: Intervening after an unusually bad period often coincides with natural rebound, creating false attribution.
hidden_timestamp: Was the menu change made immediately after an unusually bad streak that would likely regress upward anyway?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the bad streak was driven by temporary issues or noise that resolved and reviews naturally rebounded, the improvement is likely due to regression to the mean, not the menu change.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If repeated A/B tests or staggered rollouts show layout changes consistently increase ratings, then a causal effect could be supported.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here: the improvement may simply reflect regression to the mean after an extreme event, not a true effect of the menu change.
gold_rationale: The menu change was implemented right after a period of unusually bad reviews, which are likely to improve naturally due to regression to the mean and resolution of temporary issues. Without controlled testing, the causal claim is unsupported because the observed association does not imply a causal effect under intervention.

scenario: A company observes that employees who attend leadership training have higher promotion rates. The company concludes: “Leadership training causes promotions,” and decides to require the training for anyone who wants to be promoted.
claim: Requiring leadership training will cause higher promotion rates.
label: NO

Z: High-potential identification and manager sponsorship (who is nominated/encouraged to attend training)

causal_structure: Sponsorship or high-potential status (Z) causes both attending leadership training (X) and higher promotion rates (Y), so the observed association is confounded by selection bias.
key_insight: Training participation can be a marker of sponsorship, not a driver of promotion.
hidden_timestamp: Are trainees nominated as high-potential employees rather than selected randomly?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If sponsorship/high-potential status drives both training attendance and promotions, requiring training will not itself increase promotions.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If training is randomly offered within comparable groups and increases promotions holding sponsorship constant, then training could have a causal effect.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because selection bias means training attendance is not exogenous; the observed association does not imply that requiring training will cause promotions.
gold_rationale: Employees sent to leadership training are often already sponsored or identified as high-potential, which independently increases promotion odds. Therefore, requiring training based on this correlation does not establish it will cause promotions, as the association is confounded by selection bias.

scenario: A hospital compares people who got a ‘priority bed assignment’ to those who did not. People with priority beds have higher survival. The hospital claims: “Priority bed assignment saves lives,” and wants to expand it. But priority beds are given to patients who arrive earlier and have certain characteristics; staffing levels vary by shift.
claim: Expanding priority bed assignment will save lives.
label: NO

Z: Arrival time, shift staffing, and triage pathway differences that affect both bed assignment and survival

trap.subtype_name: Bed assignment correlated with staffing and triage conditions

causal_structure: Shift staffing, arrival time, and triage pathway (Z) influence both who receives a priority bed (X) and patient survival (Y), creating confounding. The observed association between X and Y does not reflect the effect of do(X) because Z is not controlled.
key_insight: Operational confounders like staffing and triage can create spurious associations between policy and outcomes.
hidden_timestamp: Are priority beds assigned based on factors (like arrival time, staffing, or triage) that also affect survival?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If priority beds are assigned based on arrival time, staffing, or triage factors that also affect survival, expanding priority beds may not improve survival because the observed association is confounded.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If priority beds are assigned randomly and survival improves, then a causal effect is plausible, but this is not established by the current observational data.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because operational confounding (shift, triage, staffing) means do(X) does not equal observed X; intervention-level inference requires designs that isolate bed assignment from these confounders.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because priority bed assignment is confounded with arrival time, staffing, and triage conditions that also affect survival. Without isolating bed assignment from these operational confounders, the observed association cannot be interpreted causally. Only a design that breaks this confounding (e.g., randomization or natural experiment) could justify the claim.

scenario: A researcher studies only people who completed a 12-week running plan. Among completers, those who ran the most miles report more knee pain. The researcher concludes: “Running causes knee pain,” and recommends reducing mileage for everyone.
claim: Reducing running mileage will reduce knee pain because running causes knee pain.
label: NO

Z: Completing the 12-week plan (conditioning on completion / attrition gate)

causal_structure: X → Z ← Y (completion depends on both running mileage tolerance and pain/injury; conditioning on Z induces a spurious association between X and Y among survivors).
key_insight: Completer-only analyses can hide dropouts due to pain and distort relationships among survivors.
hidden_timestamp: Were participants with high pain more likely to drop out and thus excluded from analysis?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If completion depends on both mileage tolerance and pain (and analysis conditions on completion), the observed association between running mileage and knee pain among completers is likely biased and does not reflect the true causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If all participants are included and attrition is properly modeled or randomized, the causal effect of running mileage on knee pain can be estimated more accurately.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the analysis conditions on completion, a collider, which can induce spurious associations. Proper causal inference requires including all participants and accounting for attrition.
gold_rationale: Because the analysis only includes those who completed the plan, it likely excludes people who dropped out due to pain. Conditioning on completion (a collider) can distort the relationship between running mileage and knee pain, so the recommendation to reduce mileage for everyone is not supported by the observed data.

scenario: A hospital provides discharge checklists. After adopting checklists, readmissions decrease. Staff claim checklists reduce readmissions by improving patient understanding of medications and follow-up.
claim: Discharge checklists reduce readmissions.
label: NO

Z: Improved patient understanding/adherence to post-discharge plan
Implementation quality of checklist (teach-back, comprehension, adherence support)

causal_structure: X → Z → Y (checklists improve understanding/adherence; adherence reduces readmissions). If Z (adherence) does not change, do(X) may not affect Y.
key_insight: Causal effect depends on the mediator; without improved adherence, checklists alone may not reduce readmissions.
hidden_timestamp: Did patient understanding and adherence actually improve (teach-back, follow-up) after checklists?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If checklists are implemented with teach-back and measurably improve adherence, readmissions may decrease.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If checklists become box-checking with no comprehension gains, readmissions will likely not decrease.

wise_refusal: I cannot attribute a causal effect to checklists alone; the intervention's impact depends on whether it actually improves patient understanding and adherence (the mediator). Without evidence of mediator change, the causal claim is invalid.
gold_rationale: The observed association between checklists and readmissions is mediated by patient understanding and adherence. If the mediator does not change, intervening on checklists (do(X)) will not necessarily reduce readmissions. The claim fails intervention-level reasoning because the causal pathway is unverified.

scenario: A school district randomly assigns half of its middle schools to adopt a new reading curriculum (X) and keeps the rest on the old curriculum. After one semester, treated schools have higher reading scores (Y). The district concludes the new curriculum improved reading performance, but it is unclear whether all schools implemented the curriculum as intended.
claim: Adopting the new reading curriculum increases reading scores.
label: NO

Z: Implementation fidelity: whether the curriculum was delivered as designed

causal_structure: Random assignment sets X, but the actual causal pathway to Y depends on whether the curriculum was truly implemented in each school. If implementation fidelity is low, do(X) does not reliably change Y, breaking the intended causal link.
key_insight: A causal claim fails if the intervention is not delivered as intended, regardless of random assignment.
hidden_timestamp: Did every school assigned to the new curriculum actually implement it with full fidelity, or did some deviate from the intended protocol?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If all assigned schools implemented the curriculum exactly as designed, the observed increase in reading scores could be attributed to the curriculum itself.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If some assigned schools did not implement the curriculum as intended, the observed association between curriculum adoption and reading scores cannot be causally attributed to the curriculum.

wise_refusal: I must refuse causal attribution because mechanism failure is possible: without confirming full implementation fidelity, adopting the curriculum does not guarantee higher reading scores under intervention.
gold_rationale: Even with random assignment, the causal effect of the curriculum on reading scores is invalid if the intervention mechanism fails—such as incomplete or incorrect curriculum delivery. This mechanism failure means do(X) does not ensure the intended change in Y, so the observed association may not reflect a true causal effect. The trap is that the causal claim is only valid if the intervention is implemented as designed.

scenario: A company notices that employees enroll in a stress-management program right after an unusually stressful month. In the following month, average stress scores are lower. The HR lead says: “We should not credit the program solely for the drop; some of it is likely regression to the mean.”
claim: The observed stress reduction after employees enroll could partly reflect regression to the mean rather than the program’s causal effect.
label: NO

Z: Temporary stress spike / random fluctuation driving enrollment timing

trap.subtype_name: Enrollment triggered by an extreme period

causal_structure: A temporary spike in stress (Z) causes both program enrollment (X) and a natural decline in stress (Y) the following month, so the observed association between X and Y can arise even if the program has no effect.
key_insight: Regression to the mean can create apparent improvement after interventions triggered by extreme values.
hidden_timestamp: Was enrollment typically prompted by unusually high stress periods?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If enrollment is usually triggered by stress spikes, much of the observed improvement is likely regression to the mean.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If enrollment is random with respect to stress level, observed improvement is more likely due to the program.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because regression to the mean can explain the observed improvement; without a proper control or randomization, we cannot infer the program's true effect.
gold_rationale: When enrollment in the program is prompted by unusually high stress, subsequent reductions in stress can occur even without any program effect, due to regression to the mean. The observed association does not imply a causal effect of the program unless we account for this selection mechanism.

scenario: A city tests a new bike-lane design on a randomly selected set of comparable streets (X). After installation, near-miss incidents (Y) decrease on treated streets compared to untreated streets observed over the same period. The city claims the design improved safety.
claim: Installing the new bike-lane design reduces near-miss incidents.
label: NO

trap.subtype_name: Compare treated vs untreated same time

causal_structure: Randomization and concurrent controls aim to block confounding, but unmeasured spillover effects (such as drivers rerouting from treated to untreated streets) or inconsistent measurement could bias the observed association, so do(X) may not equal the observed effect.
key_insight: Even with randomization and concurrent controls, unmeasured spillover or inconsistent measurement can invalidate causal claims.
hidden_timestamp: Were untreated streets measured during the same period with the same near-miss definition, and could spillover effects bias the comparison?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If untreated streets were measured concurrently and no spillover or measurement bias occurred, the causal claim would be more credible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If spillover effects or inconsistent measurement exist, the observed association does not reflect the true effect of the bike-lane design.

wise_refusal: Refuse to attribute causality because potential spillover effects and measurement inconsistencies could confound the intervention, violating the assumptions needed for do(X) to equal the observed association (Confounding).
gold_rationale: Although randomization and concurrent controls are strong design features, unmeasured spillover (e.g., drivers rerouting from treated to untreated streets) or inconsistent measurement could bias the results. Therefore, the observed association does not necessarily imply that installing the new bike-lane design causes reduced near-miss incidents under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A clinician is evaluating a new migraine medication (X). They note that patients usually seek treatment right after an unusually severe migraine week. The clinician says: “We should expect symptoms to improve next week even without medication, so we need a control group.”
claim: Starting migraine medication causes migraine severity to improve the next week.
label: NO
causal_structure: An extreme baseline week (Z) increases the chance of starting medication (X) and also predicts natural improvement in symptoms (Y) due to regression to the mean, even if X has no effect.
key_insight: Apparent improvement after starting treatment may simply reflect natural regression to the mean, not a true medication effect.
hidden_timestamp: Do patients typically start medication right after unusually severe weeks?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If patients start medication after a symptom peak, improvement may occur naturally regardless of medication.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If treatment is started randomly, observed improvement is more likely attributable to the medication.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because regression to the mean can explain the observed improvement; a control group or randomization is needed to isolate the medication's effect.
gold_rationale: The observed pre/post improvement after starting migraine medication may be due to regression to the mean, since patients tend to seek treatment after unusually severe weeks. Without a control group, we cannot attribute improvement to the medication itself. The causal claim is invalid under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A teacher wants to know whether tutoring (X) improves math scores (Y). The teacher says: “If I only look at students who stayed in the tutoring program for the full semester (Z = ‘completed tutoring’), I may bias the results because struggling students might drop out.”
claim: Receiving tutoring caused higher end-of-semester math scores, based on only analyzing students who completed the tutoring program.
label: NO
causal_structure: Conditioning on Z (completion) opens a backdoor path from X to Y through unmeasured factors (U) that affect both completion and math scores, creating selection bias.
key_insight: Analyzing only those who complete a program can introduce selection bias if completion is related to unmeasured factors affecting the outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Do dropout/completion patterns depend on motivation or baseline difficulty that also affects scores?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If completion depends on motivation or baseline ability, the observed effect of tutoring among completers is biased.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If completion is random and unrelated to ability or motivation, selection bias is less likely.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because conditioning on completion introduces selection bias; the observed association among completers does not reflect the true effect of tutoring under intervention.
gold_rationale: Conditioning on students who complete tutoring selects a non-random group, potentially influenced by unmeasured factors like motivation or baseline ability. This selection opens a backdoor path between tutoring and scores, so the observed association among completers does not represent the causal effect of tutoring. The correct approach would analyze all students assigned to tutoring (intent-to-treat) or properly account for dropout mechanisms.

scenario: A gym chain pilots an ‘attendance reminder’ text message (X) by randomly selecting half of new members to receive the messages. After 8 weeks, the treated group attends more sessions (Y). The chain concludes reminders increase attendance.
claim: Sending attendance reminder texts increases gym attendance.
label: NO
causal_structure: If baseline motivation affects both likelihood of attending the gym and responsiveness to reminders, but randomization is imperfect or there is noncompliance, confounding remains possible. The observed association may reflect mediation or residual confounding.
key_insight: Randomization only isolates the effect if compliance is perfect and there is no post-randomization bias.
hidden_timestamp: Was there perfect compliance with random assignment, or did motivated members self-select into the reminder group post-randomization?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If compliance was perfect and no selection occurred after randomization, the causal claim is supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If motivated members were more likely to receive or respond to reminders despite randomization, the observed effect may be confounded.

wise_refusal: I cannot attribute causality to reminders without knowing whether randomization was strictly enforced and there was no post-assignment selection or compliance bias; intervention-level confounding vs mediation remains unresolved.
gold_rationale: Even with randomization, if there is noncompliance or post-randomization selection (e.g., motivated members are more likely to receive or act on reminders), the observed association may not reflect the true causal effect of reminders. The trap is failing to distinguish between confounding and mediation when randomization is imperfect.

scenario: A homeowner tests whether a new air purifier (X) reduces indoor allergy symptoms (Y). They measure symptoms during a high-pollen week, buy the purifier, then measure again during a lower-pollen week. They say: “This is not a fair test because pollen levels changed.”
claim: Using the new air purifier caused the reduction in allergy symptoms.
label: NO

Z: Outdoor pollen level during measurement week

trap.subtype_name: Pollen levels changed between pre and post measurements

causal_structure: Outdoor pollen level (Z) affects allergy symptoms (Y) and varies over time; the naive pre/post comparison mixes the effect of the purifier (X) with changes in pollen (Z), so do(X) is not isolated.
key_insight: Pre/post comparisons without controlling for background variables like pollen can confound the effect of the intervention.
hidden_timestamp: Did pollen levels differ substantially between the pre and post weeks?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If pollen levels were similar in both weeks, any change in symptoms could be attributed more confidently to the purifier.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If pollen levels dropped after installing the purifier, the observed symptom reduction could be due to pollen, not the purifier.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the observed association between purifier use and symptom reduction is confounded by changes in pollen levels; intervention on X (purifier) does not isolate the effect without controlling for Z (pollen).
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because the reduction in allergy symptoms could be explained by lower pollen levels rather than the air purifier. Without controlling for this confounder, the observed association does not imply a causal effect of the purifier under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A student tries a new study app (X) right after receiving a very low quiz score. The next quiz score (Y) is higher. The student says: “Part of this improvement could be regression to the mean; I shouldn’t conclude the app caused the jump from one quiz.”
claim: A jump in score after a very low quiz can reflect regression to the mean, so one pre/post comparison is insufficient to claim the app caused improvement.
label: NO

Z: Random fluctuation / unusually bad quiz day prompting app adoption

trap.subtype_name: Intervention starts after an extreme low outcome

causal_structure: An unusually low quiz score (Z) prompts adoption of the app (X); scores naturally regress toward the average (Y), so improvement may occur even without the app.
key_insight: Starting an intervention after an unusually poor outcome inflates apparent improvement.
hidden_timestamp: Was the first quiz unusually low relative to typical performance?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the first quiz was unusually low, improvement may reflect regression to the mean, not the app.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the first quiz was typical, improvement could be more plausibly attributed to the app.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because starting the app after an extreme low score creates regression to the mean; one pre/post comparison cannot establish the app's effect.
gold_rationale: Regression to the mean means that extreme scores tend to be followed by less extreme ones, regardless of intervention. Since the app was adopted after a very low score, the observed improvement could occur even without the app. Thus, the claim that the app caused the improvement is invalid under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A city offers free smoke alarms (X) and wants to know if they reduce fire-related injuries (Y). An analyst says: “If we only analyze homes that requested an alarm (Z = ‘requested’), we’ll bias results because riskier households may be more likely to request.”
claim: Restricting analysis to households that request alarms can bias the estimated effect of providing alarms.
label: NO
causal_structure: Conditioning on Z (requesting an alarm), which is influenced by both X (receiving an alarm) and unmeasured risk factors (U), opens a backdoor path from X to Y through U, biasing the estimated effect of X on Y.
key_insight: Restricting analysis to self-selected requesters can introduce selection bias and distort causal inference.
hidden_timestamp: Are higher-risk households (older wiring, smokers) more likely to request alarms?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If higher-risk households are more likely to request alarms, restricting to requesters will bias the effect estimate.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If requesting is random and unrelated to risk, restricting to requesters may not introduce bias, but this is rarely the case.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because conditioning on requesters (selection bias) can distort the estimated effect of receiving a smoke alarm on fire-related injury risk.
gold_rationale: Restricting analysis to households that request alarms conditions on a variable (requesting) that is influenced by both the exposure and unmeasured risk factors. This selection bias can open a backdoor path and confound the estimated effect, making the causal claim invalid under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A researcher evaluates a sleep workshop (X) and proposes controlling for ‘sleep quality after the workshop’ (Z) when estimating the workshop’s effect on mood (Y). A colleague says: “Don’t control for post-treatment sleep quality; it’s part of the mechanism.”
claim: Controlling for post-treatment sleep quality can block part of the workshop’s effect on mood and bias the estimate (post-treatment adjustment).
label: NO

Z: Sleep quality after attending the workshop

trap.subtype_name: Adjusting for Z that lies on the causal path

causal_structure: X → Z → Y; controlling for Z (a mediator) blocks the indirect path from X to Y, distorting the total effect of X on Y.
key_insight: Controlling for a mediator can block the causal pathway and bias the estimate of the total effect.
hidden_timestamp: Is sleep quality measured after the intervention (post-treatment), or is it a pre-existing variable?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If sleep quality is measured after the workshop (post-treatment), controlling for it blocks part of the effect of X on Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If sleep quality is a pre-existing variable, controlling for it may help adjust for confounding, but that's not the case here.

wise_refusal: Refuse to attribute a valid causal effect estimate under intervention: controlling for a post-treatment mediator (Z) blocks part of the effect of X on Y, which is an error of confusing mediation with confounding.
gold_rationale: Controlling for a mediator (post-treatment variable) when estimating the total effect of X on Y is inappropriate because it blocks the indirect pathway through which X affects Y. This confuses mediation with confounding and leads to biased estimates under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A company changes its customer support script (X) and sees customer satisfaction (Y) rise afterward. A manager says: “Before crediting the script, we should check whether there was also a product outage that ended (Z) right after we changed the script.”
claim: The new customer support script caused the increase in customer satisfaction.
label: NO

Z: Product outage status or incident severity

trap.subtype_name: Outage ended at same time as script change

causal_structure: A concurrent event (Z, such as an outage ending) affects both the timing of the script change (X) and customer satisfaction (Y), so the observed association between X and Y may be due to Z, not X. Intervening on X alone (do(X)) does not guarantee the same effect unless Z is controlled.
key_insight: Concurrent changes can confound before/after comparisons, invalidating simple causal claims.
hidden_timestamp: Did any major incident or outage end at the same time as the script rollout?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If a major outage ended concurrently with the script change, the satisfaction increase may be due to the outage resolution, not the script.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If no other major events occurred, the script change is more likely to be responsible for the satisfaction increase.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution to the script alone is invalid without ruling out confounding by concurrent events such as an outage ending; intervention-level reasoning requires controlling for Z.
gold_rationale: The observed rise in customer satisfaction after the script change could be explained by a confounding event (e.g., an outage ending) that occurred at the same time. Without controlling for such concurrent changes, we cannot attribute the effect to the script itself under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A restaurant wants to estimate whether offering live music nights (X) increases revenue (Y). The owner says: “If we only analyze nights when the restaurant is busy (Z = ‘high foot traffic’), we might create a misleading relationship because busyness is influenced by both music and other factors.”
claim: Offering live music causes higher nightly revenue.
label: NO

Z: High foot traffic / busyness is a collider affected by both live music and other factors influencing revenue

trap.subtype_name: Busyness is affected by multiple causes

causal_structure: Live music (X) and other factors (U) both affect busyness (Z), and U also affects revenue (Y). Conditioning on Z opens a backdoor path from X to Y through U, biasing the estimated effect of X on Y.
key_insight: Conditioning on a collider like busyness can create spurious associations between intervention and outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Is busyness affected both by live music and other drivers (weather, holidays) that also affect revenue?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If busyness is affected by both live music and other factors that also affect revenue, conditioning on busyness will bias the estimated effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If busyness is only affected by live music and not by other factors influencing revenue, conditioning may not introduce bias.

wise_refusal: Refuse to attribute a causal effect of live music on revenue based on this analysis, because conditioning on busyness (a collider) introduces collider bias and invalidates the intervention inference.
gold_rationale: Conditioning on busyness, which is influenced by both live music and other factors that also affect revenue, opens a backdoor path and creates a spurious association. Thus, the observed association does not reflect the true causal effect of live music on revenue under intervention.

scenario: A teacher gives extra help sessions to students who scored the lowest on the midterm (X = “received help because bottom 10%”). On the final, those students’ scores (Y) improve substantially. The teacher says: “Some improvement is expected even without help because we selected the lowest scorers; we need a control group to estimate the help’s true effect.”
claim: Score improvements among the lowest midterm scorers can partly reflect regression to the mean, so a control group is needed to estimate the causal effect of extra help.
label: NO

X.name: Receiving extra help (assigned because bottom 10% midterm)

Z: Random factors that made the midterm unusually low (bad day / test noise)

trap.subtype_name: Treatment triggered by extreme low baseline

causal_structure: Random factors (Z) cause both selection into extra help (X) and predict natural improvement in final scores (Y), so observed gains may reflect regression to the mean rather than a true effect of X.
key_insight: Selecting based on extreme low performance makes later improvement likely even without intervention.
hidden_timestamp: Was extra help targeted specifically at the lowest midterm scorers?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If extra help was targeted at the lowest scorers, observed improvement may largely reflect regression to the mean.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If extra help was randomly assigned, improvement could be more confidently attributed to the intervention.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because selection based on extreme low scores introduces regression to the mean; a control group is needed to separate natural improvement from intervention effects.
gold_rationale: Because students were selected for help based on extreme low midterm scores, some later improvement is expected from regression to the mean. The observed association between help and improvement does not justify a causal effect under intervention reasoning. A control group or randomization is required to estimate the true effect of extra help.

scenario: A coach assigns a new stretching routine to athletes only after they have their worst flexibility test of the season (X = “given routine after extreme low flexibility”). The next test (Y) is higher. The coach says: “Part of the improvement could just be regression to the mean from an unusually bad test day.”
claim: Starting the stretching routine after an extreme low flexibility test causes improvement in the next flexibility test score.
label: NO

X.name: Starting stretching routine (triggered by worst flexibility test)

Z: Measurement noise or transient stiffness on the worst test day
Extreme low flexibility test triggers routine assignment

causal_structure: An extreme low flexibility test (Z) increases the chance of being assigned the routine (X), and also predicts improvement in the next test (Y) due to regression to the mean, regardless of the routine's effect.
key_insight: Assigning interventions based on extreme values creates apparent improvement even without a true causal effect.
hidden_timestamp: Was the routine assigned specifically after the worst test, not randomly?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the routine is assigned after an extreme low, improvement may reflect regression to the mean, not a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the routine is assigned randomly, observed improvement could be attributed to the routine.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the intervention is triggered by an extreme measurement, introducing regression to the mean bias.
gold_rationale: Because the stretching routine is assigned after an unusually bad flexibility test, any subsequent improvement may simply reflect regression to the mean rather than a true effect of the routine. The observed association does not imply that starting the routine caused the improvement; a randomized assignment or comparison group is needed to estimate the causal effect.

scenario: A doctor prescribes a new asthma inhaler to patients right after their worst symptom flare in months (X = “start inhaler after severe flare”). At the next visit, symptoms (Y) are improved. The doctor says: “We need to be careful; symptoms might improve anyway after a flare.”
claim: Starting the new inhaler after a severe flare caused the improvement in symptoms at the next visit.
label: NO

X.name: Starting the new inhaler after severe flare

Z: Natural fluctuation in symptom severity / flare dynamics

causal_structure: Natural symptom fluctuations (Z) cause both the severe flare that triggers treatment (X) and the subsequent improvement (Y), so the observed association does not reflect a true causal effect of X on Y.
key_insight: Apparent improvement after treatment may simply reflect regression to the mean, not a true treatment effect.
hidden_timestamp: Was treatment typically initiated right after unusually severe flares?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If treatment is always started after extreme flares, improvement may occur even without a treatment effect due to regression to the mean.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If treatment is started randomly (not tied to flares), improvement would more likely reflect a true treatment effect.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because regression to the mean can explain the improvement; the intervention (do(X)) does not guarantee a causal effect on Y without ruling out natural symptom fluctuation.
gold_rationale: Because the inhaler is started after an extreme flare, subsequent symptom improvement may reflect natural fluctuation and regression to the mean rather than a true causal effect of the inhaler. The observed association does not justify a causal claim under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A call center introduces a coaching session (X) for agents who had the worst customer satisfaction scores last week. This week, those agents’ scores (Y) improve. A supervisor says: “Because we picked the worst performers, some improvement is expected regardless of coaching.”
claim: Receiving coaching (X) caused an improvement in customer satisfaction scores (Y) for the worst-performing agents.
label: NO

Z: Random variation in call difficulty / bad-luck week
Selection based on extreme low baseline performance

trap.subtype_name: Intervention triggered by extreme low outcome

causal_structure: Random variation (Z) causes some agents to have unusually low scores, leading to their selection for coaching (X). Even without coaching, their scores (Y) would likely improve next week due to regression to the mean.
key_insight: Improvement after intervention can reflect regression to the mean when selection is based on extreme outcomes.
hidden_timestamp: Were coached agents selected specifically because they had the worst scores last week?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If agents were selected for coaching due to extreme low scores, improvement may reflect regression to the mean, not coaching.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If coaching was assigned randomly, improvement could be attributed to the coaching effect.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because selecting agents based on extreme low scores introduces regression to the mean; the observed improvement may not be due to coaching.
gold_rationale: When coaching is assigned to agents with the lowest prior scores, subsequent improvement can occur simply due to random fluctuation (regression to the mean), not the effect of coaching. Without a randomized control group, we cannot attribute the improvement to the intervention.

scenario: A person starts a new ‘focus supplement’ (X) immediately after an unusually unproductive week at work. The next week (Y) they feel more productive. They say: “I can’t credit the supplement based on one bad week followed by one better week; regression to the mean could explain it.”
claim: Starting the supplement caused the improvement in productivity.
label: NO

X.name: Starting the focus supplement (after unusually bad week)

Z: Random workload fluctuations or transient illness/stress causing the bad week

trap.subtype_name: Intervention triggered by extreme low baseline

causal_structure: Random negative events (Z) cause both the bad week (triggering supplement start, X) and a likely natural rebound in productivity (Y) the following week, even without any supplement effect.
key_insight: Apparent improvement after starting an intervention at a low point may simply reflect regression to the mean, not a true causal effect.
hidden_timestamp: Was the supplement started right after an unusually unproductive week?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the supplement was started after an unusually bad week, improvement may reflect regression to the mean, not a supplement effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the supplement was started at a random time, improvement is less likely to be explained by regression to the mean.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because the intervention was triggered by an extreme low point; regression to the mean can explain the observed improvement under do(X).
gold_rationale: The supplement was started after an unusually unproductive week, so improvement the following week is expected even without any treatment effect due to regression to the mean. The observed association does not justify a causal effect under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A clinic enrolls patients into a weight-loss counseling program (X) only if they gained the most weight in the past month (extreme gain). The following month, average weight gain (Y) slows. The program lead says: “Some slowdown might happen anyway because we enrolled people right after an extreme gain.”
claim: Enrollment in the counseling program (X) caused the slowing of weight gain the following month (Y).
label: NO

X.name: Enrollment in counseling program (after extreme weight gain)

Z: Short-term fluctuation in weight (water retention, measurement variability)
Selection based on extreme recent gain

trap.subtype_name: Selection based on extreme recent change

causal_structure: Short-term fluctuations (Z) cause both extreme recent weight gain (triggering X) and a likely reversion in subsequent weight change (Y), so do(X) does not guarantee the observed association.
key_insight: Regression to the mean can make interventions appear effective when selection is based on extreme values.
hidden_timestamp: Were participants selected because they gained the most weight recently, or would enrollment have occurred regardless of recent weight change?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If selection was based on extreme recent gain, subsequent slowing is expected even without the program.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If selection was random, a true program effect could be estimated.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because regression to the mean, not the intervention, explains the observed slowdown; selection on extreme gain creates a spurious association under intervention reasoning.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because patients were enrolled after extreme weight gain, so subsequent slowing is expected due to natural fluctuation (regression to the mean), not necessarily the program. The observed association does not imply a causal effect of the intervention.

scenario: A manager gives performance feedback (X) to employees immediately after their worst customer interaction scores. The next month, scores (Y) improve. The manager says: “I should expect some improvement anyway because I targeted the lowest scores.”
claim: Feedback after the worst scores caused the improvement in next month's customer interaction scores.
label: NO

X.name: Receiving feedback (triggered by worst interaction scores)

Z: Randomly difficult customer mix or transient stress during the worst period

causal_structure: Extreme low scores (Z) trigger feedback (X); Z also causes low Y in the initial period, but Y naturally improves next month due to regression to the mean, regardless of X.
key_insight: Improvements after interventions triggered by extreme lows can reflect regression to the mean, not a true causal effect.
hidden_timestamp: Was feedback assigned based on unusually low scores, or was it randomized across all employees?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If feedback is triggered by extreme low scores, improvement may occur even without feedback due to regression to the mean.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If feedback is randomized, any improvement can be more confidently attributed to the feedback itself.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the observed improvement may simply reflect regression to the mean, not a true effect of feedback; intervention-level reasoning requires randomization or proper controls.
gold_rationale: Because feedback is delivered after an extreme low period, improvements can occur due to reversion from transient adverse conditions (regression to the mean). The observed association does not justify a causal claim under intervention reasoning unless feedback is randomized or compared to a proper control group.

scenario: A homeowner replaces their internet router (X) right after the worst week of connection drops they have experienced. The next week (Y) the connection is more stable. The homeowner says: “The worst week might have been a fluke; I can’t be sure the router caused the improvement.”
claim: Replacing the router caused the improvement in connection stability the following week.
label: NO

X.name: Replacing the router after worst outage week

Z: Transient ISP issues or temporary interference could have caused the worst week
Extreme bad week triggers replacement, but issues may resolve naturally

causal_structure: A transient external factor (Z) causes both the extreme outage (leading to router replacement, X) and the subsequent improvement (Y) as the factor resolves, so the observed improvement may not be due to X.
key_insight: Improvements after interventions at extreme lows may reflect natural fluctuation, not true causal effect.
hidden_timestamp: Was the worst week caused by a temporary ISP problem or interference that resolved on its own?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the worst week was due to a temporary ISP issue that resolved, the improvement would have happened even without replacing the router.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the router was truly faulty and the ISP was stable, replacing the router would cause the improvement.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because regression to the mean can explain the observed improvement; intervening on the router after an extreme week does not guarantee a causal effect.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because the improvement in connection stability may simply reflect regression to the mean after an unusually bad week, not a true effect of replacing the router. Without ruling out transient ISP issues or random fluctuation, we cannot attribute the improvement to the intervention.

scenario: A school launches an attendance incentive (X) and targets it only to students who had the worst attendance in the previous month. The next month, those students’ attendance (Y) improves. An analyst says: “Some improvement is expected anyway because we selected the worst month.”
claim: Receiving the attendance incentive caused an improvement in attendance rate among students with the worst prior attendance.
label: NO

X.name: Receiving the attendance incentive (assigned to worst prior attendance)

Z: Temporary illness or family disruption causing the worst attendance month
Selection based on extreme low attendance (regression to the mean)

trap.subtype_name: Intervention triggered by extreme low attendance

causal_structure: Students are selected for the incentive based on an unusually bad attendance month, often due to temporary disruptions (Z). These disruptions can resolve naturally, causing attendance to improve even without the incentive. Thus, the observed improvement after intervention can be explained by regression to the mean, not necessarily by the effect of the incentive.
key_insight: Selecting students based on extreme low attendance creates an illusion of program effect due to natural rebound.
hidden_timestamp: Were students chosen specifically because they had the worst attendance last month, or was assignment random?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If students were selected due to the worst prior attendance, improvement may reflect regression to the mean, not the incentive.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If assignment was random, observed improvement could be attributed to the incentive.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because selecting students based on extreme prior attendance creates regression to the mean; the observed improvement cannot be attributed to the incentive without a proper control group.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because students were targeted for the incentive after an extreme low-attendance month, which is often due to transient factors. Even without the incentive, their attendance would likely improve in the following month (regression to the mean). Therefore, the observed association does not justify a causal effect of the incentive under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A person starts a new sleep supplement (X) on Monday. By Tuesday they report higher daytime energy (Y). They conclude: “The supplement increased my energy.” A friend asks: “Did your energy already start improving over the weekend because your stressful project ended (Z)?”
claim: Because energy improved after starting the supplement, the supplement caused the improvement.
label: NO

Z: Timing of stress relief from a major project ending
Temporal order of energy improvement relative to supplement start

trap.subtype_name: Outcome trend may begin before the supposed cause

causal_structure: If energy (Y) begins improving before the supplement (X) is started, X cannot be the cause; Z (project ending) may drive both the improvement in Y and the timing of X.
key_insight: Temporal order is critical: an outcome trend that starts before the intervention cannot be caused by it.
hidden_timestamp: Did energy start improving before Monday (right after the project ended), or only after starting the supplement?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If energy began improving before the supplement was started, the supplement cannot be the cause.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If energy only improved after starting the supplement and no other major change occurred, causality is still uncertain due to possible confounding or placebo effects.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid without establishing that the outcome trend began after the intervention; this is a temporal ambiguity problem.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because if the improvement in energy began before the supplement was started, the supplement cannot be the cause. Even if the timing aligns, other factors like stress relief (Z) could explain the change. The key flaw is temporal ambiguity: without clear evidence that the outcome followed the intervention, causal inference is not justified.

scenario: A city opens a new bike lane (X). That same month, average commute time (Y) drops. Officials claim: “The bike lane reduced commute time.” A resident notes: “The drop started two weeks before the lane opened because a bridge construction project ended (Z).”
claim: The new bike lane caused the commute-time drop because the drop was observed around the time the lane opened.
label: NO

Z: Bridge construction ending (road capacity restored) and its timing

causal_structure: The observed drop in commute time began before the bike lane opened, indicating that the timing of the exposure (X) does not align with the outcome (Y). Instead, the end of bridge construction (Z) caused the earlier drop, so intervening on X would not reproduce the observed effect.
key_insight: If the outcome changes before the intervention, the intervention cannot be its cause.
hidden_timestamp: Did commute times begin improving before the bike lane opened (matching the construction end)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If commute times began dropping before the bike lane opened, the bike lane cannot be the cause.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If commute times only dropped after the bike lane opened, then the bike lane could plausibly be responsible.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the outcome (commute time drop) started before the intervention (bike lane opening); this is a temporal ambiguity trap.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because the observed effect (drop in commute time) began before the intervention (bike lane opening). This temporal mismatch means that intervening to open the bike lane would not necessarily cause the observed drop, as the true cause was the end of bridge construction. The trap is temporal ambiguity: confusing correlation around an event with causation by that event.

scenario: A manager wants to improve ‘productivity’ and starts rewarding employees based on number of emails sent per day (Y). After the policy (X), email counts rise and the manager concludes: “Productivity increased.”
claim: Because email counts rose after the incentive policy, true productivity increased.
label: NO

Y.name: Number of emails sent per day (proxy metric)

Z: True productivity / valuable work output (the real target)
Proxy metric can be manipulated without affecting the real outcome

causal_structure: The incentive policy (X) directly increases the proxy metric (Y: emails sent), but Y is not a valid measure of true productivity (Z). Thus, intervening on X only guarantees more emails, not more valuable work.
key_insight: Incentivizing a proxy metric can decouple it from the true target, invalidating causal claims about the real outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Does increasing email count actually reflect an increase in true productivity, or can employees send more emails without improving valuable output?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If email count reflects real work, productivity increases.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If email count can be inflated without real output, productivity does not increase.

wise_refusal: Refuse to attribute a causal effect from the incentive policy to true productivity because the proxy metric (emails sent) can be manipulated independently of the actual target, illustrating Goodhart’s Law.
gold_rationale: The observed increase in emails is a result of incentivizing a proxy metric, which can be gamed without improving true productivity. This is a classic Goodhart’s Law trap: optimizing the proxy breaks its relationship with the real goal, so intervening on X does not guarantee a causal effect on the intended outcome.

scenario: A school adopts a new reading program (X) and tracks ‘minutes logged on the reading app’ (Y) as evidence of improved literacy. App minutes increase, and administrators conclude: “Students are reading better now.”
claim: An increase in app minutes after adopting the program means literacy improved.
label: NO

Z: App minutes can be inflated without true learning

trap.subtype_name: Engagement proxy may not track learning

causal_structure: Adopting the program (X) increases app minutes (Y), but Y is only a proxy for true literacy (Z). Y can rise due to compliance or gaming the metric, not actual improvement in Z.
key_insight: Proxy metrics like app minutes can be manipulated and do not guarantee improvement in the real outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Can students increase app minutes without actually improving reading comprehension?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If app minutes reflect real reading, literacy may improve.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If app minutes are inflated without real engagement, literacy does not improve.

wise_refusal: Refuse to attribute causality: The intervention only increases a proxy metric (app minutes), not necessarily true literacy. This is a mechanism failure at the intervention level.
gold_rationale: The observed increase in app minutes does not guarantee improved literacy, as the metric can be manipulated or reflect compliance rather than genuine learning. The causal claim fails because the proxy does not reliably measure the intended outcome.

scenario: A restaurant starts offering a small discount to customers who leave a review (X). After the change, the average star rating (Y) rises. The owner concludes: “The food quality improved.”
claim: The discount policy caused food quality to improve because star ratings increased after the policy.
label: NO

X.name: Offering a discount for leaving a review

Z: Who leaves reviews and how they respond under incentives (reviewer mix/behavior)
Incentives change the measurement process (ratings reflect reporting, not necessarily quality)

trap.subtype_name: Policy changes who reports and what gets reported

causal_structure: Offering a discount (X) changes who leaves reviews and how they rate (Z), which alters the average star rating (Y) even if food quality does not change. The observed association does not reflect a true causal effect of X on food quality.
key_insight: Incentives can distort outcome measures, so observed changes may not reflect real improvements.
hidden_timestamp: Did the discount change who leaves reviews (composition) or how they rate, rather than changing food quality?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the discount only changed who reviews or how they rate, the higher ratings do not indicate improved food quality.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the discount actually led to improved food quality, then the higher ratings could reflect a real improvement.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the intervention (discount) changes the measurement process, not necessarily the underlying quality; this is a mechanism failure at the intervention level.
gold_rationale: The observed increase in ratings could be due to changes in who leaves reviews or how they rate, not an actual improvement in food quality. The intervention affects the reporting mechanism, so the claim that the discount caused food quality to improve is invalid.

scenario: A fitness app introduces a ‘daily streak’ badge (X) and sends more push notifications to keep streaks alive. After rollout, users’ reported workouts (Y) increase. The app team concludes: “The badge increased real exercise.”
claim: The badge feature caused users to exercise more because reported workouts increased after rollout.
label: NO

Z: User logging/recording behavior (compliance/gaming) vs actual exercise
Measurement error due to incentives to log rather than exercise

causal_structure: The intervention (X) increases incentives to log workouts (Z), which can inflate reported workouts (Y) without increasing actual exercise. Thus, do(X) may not affect true exercise, only reporting.
key_insight: Reported outcomes can be contaminated by feedback effects when incentives change how people report, not what they do.
hidden_timestamp: Are reported workouts objectively verified, or can users easily log activity without real exercise?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If reported workouts are tightly verified by objective sensors and cannot be gamed, the increase might reflect real exercise.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If logging can be easily gamed or reminders mainly increase reporting, the metric can rise without any real change in exercise.

wise_refusal: Refuse to attribute causality: The intervention may only increase reported workouts via feedback on logging, not actual exercise. This is a feedback loop trap at the intervention level.
gold_rationale: The observed increase in reported workouts may result from users adapting their logging behavior to maintain streaks, not from exercising more. The intervention changes incentives to report, creating a feedback loop that contaminates the outcome measure. Without objective verification, we cannot conclude that do(X) increases true exercise.

scenario: People who buy organic groceries (X) in a neighborhood tend to have lower rates of obesity (Y). A blogger claims: “Buying organic causes people to be healthier.”
claim: Buying organic groceries causes lower obesity rates.
label: NO

Z: Socioeconomic status and health-oriented lifestyle (diet, exercise, healthcare access)

trap.subtype_name: A common cause drives both purchase and health

causal_structure: Socioeconomic status and health-oriented lifestyle (Z) influence both buying organic groceries (X) and obesity rates (Y), creating a spurious association between X and Y.
key_insight: A confounder can explain an observed association, invalidating a direct causal claim.
hidden_timestamp: Are people who buy organic groceries also more likely to have higher socioeconomic status or health-oriented lifestyles that independently reduce obesity?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If organic buyers are more health-conscious or wealthier, the association is likely confounded.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If organic buying is randomly assigned and not related to SES or lifestyle, a causal effect could be inferred.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because confounding by socioeconomic status and health-oriented lifestyle cannot be ruled out without intervention or proper adjustment.
gold_rationale: The observed association between buying organic groceries and lower obesity rates can be explained by confounding: people with higher SES or health-oriented lifestyles are both more likely to buy organic and to have lower obesity, so intervening on organic grocery buying alone may not change obesity rates.

scenario: Students who attend after-school enrichment clubs (X) tend to have higher grades (Y). A parent concludes: “The clubs cause higher grades.”
claim: After-school enrichment clubs cause students to earn higher grades.
label: NO

trap.subtype_name: Support/resources drive both participation and grades

causal_structure: Parental support and student motivation (Z) influence both attending clubs (X) and student grades (Y), creating a confounding bias in the observed association.
key_insight: Self-selection into beneficial activities often reflects prior advantages that also drive outcomes.
hidden_timestamp: Are students who attend clubs also more motivated or supported at home in ways that affect grades?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If students who attend clubs are more motivated or supported, then the observed association is confounded and not causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If club attendance is randomly assigned, then a causal effect could be inferred.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because confounding by parental support and motivation means do(X) does not equal the observed association; only a randomized or controlled design can justify the claim.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because students who attend after-school clubs may differ systematically in parental support or motivation, which also affect grades. Without controlling for these confounders or using random assignment, the observed association does not imply that club attendance causes higher grades.

scenario: A budgeting app reports that users who enabled ‘automatic savings’ (X) saved more money over three months (Y). The company claims: “Turning on auto-savings causes people to save more.”
claim: Enabling auto-savings causes users to save more money.
label: NO

Z: Pre-existing motivation or financial stability that influences both opting in and saving

causal_structure: A confounder (motivation/financial stability) affects both the likelihood of enabling auto-savings and the amount saved, so the observed association does not reflect the causal effect of enabling auto-savings.
key_insight: Opt-in features often attract users already inclined to the desired behavior, inflating estimated effects.
hidden_timestamp: Were users who enabled auto-savings already saving more or more financially stable before enabling the feature?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If enabling auto-savings was randomized among comparable users, a causal effect could be inferred.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If enabling is purely opt-in and motivated savers disproportionately enable it, the association is likely due to selection bias, not causality.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here due to selection bias: users who opt in to auto-savings may already be more motivated or financially stable, so intervening on auto-savings would not necessarily increase saving for everyone.
gold_rationale: Because enabling auto-savings is opt-in, differences in savings may reflect who chooses the feature rather than the feature itself causing increased saving. Without randomization or controlling for motivation/financial stability, the observed association does not justify a causal claim.

scenario: A company offers an optional leadership workshop (X). Six months later, workshop attendees have higher promotion rates (Y). HR concludes: “The workshop increases promotions.”
claim: Attending the optional leadership workshop causes higher promotion rates.
label: NO

trap.subtype_name: High-potential employees are more likely to attend

causal_structure: Pre-existing high potential (Z) influences both the likelihood of attending the workshop (X) and being promoted (Y), so observed associations may reflect selection rather than a true effect of the workshop.
key_insight: Optional programs often attract people already on a promotion track, making simple comparisons misleading.
hidden_timestamp: Were attendees disproportionately identified as high potential before the workshop?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If attendance was randomized among eligible employees, the causal effect could be estimated without selection bias.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If high-potential employees disproportionately attend, promotion differences can be explained by pre-existing potential rather than the workshop.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because selection bias means do(X) does not equal observed X; random assignment or strong controls are needed to justify a causal claim.
gold_rationale: Because the workshop is optional, attendance is confounded by motivation or high-potential selection, which also predicts promotion. Without randomization or controlling for these factors, the observed association does not justify a causal effect under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A survey finds that people who attend exclusive networking events tend to have higher incomes than those who do not.
claim: Attending exclusive networking events caused people to have higher incomes.
label: NO

Z: Selection bias due to only surveying event attendees and high earners

causal_structure: The observed association arises because the sample is restricted to people who attend exclusive events or already have high incomes, not because attending the event itself causes higher income; intervening on attendance would not yield the same effect in the general population.
key_insight: Selection bias can create spurious associations that do not reflect true causal effects.
hidden_timestamp: Were individuals with lower incomes equally likely to be included in the survey regardless of event attendance?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If low-income individuals were included, the association may disappear.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only high-income attendees were surveyed, the association is likely spurious.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because selection bias distorts the observed association; intervening to make someone attend the event would not necessarily increase their income.
gold_rationale: Selection bias occurs when the sample is not representative of the general population. In this case, only surveying event attendees or high earners creates an artificial association between event attendance and income. Under intervention (do(X)), making someone attend the event does not guarantee a change in income, as the observed association is due to biased sampling, not a true causal link.

scenario: A magazine reports that people who attend exclusive networking events are more likely to be successful entrepreneurs, based on a survey of event attendees.
claim: Attending exclusive networking events causes people to become successful entrepreneurs.
label: NO

Z: Selection bias due to only surveying event attendees

causal_structure: The observed association is distorted because only those who attend the events (and may already be on the path to success) are included, ignoring those who did not attend or failed, so intervening on event attendance does not guarantee the same outcome.
key_insight: Survivorship bias can make it look like an exposure causes success when failures are systematically excluded.
hidden_timestamp: Were unsuccessful entrepreneurs or non-attendees included in the survey sample?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If unsuccessful entrepreneurs and non-attendees were included, the association may disappear.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only successful attendees were surveyed, the association is likely spurious.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because the observed association is due to survivorship bias: intervening to make someone attend does not account for those who attended but did not become successful.
gold_rationale: This is a classic case of survivorship bias: the sample only includes those who attended the events and became successful, ignoring those who attended but failed or never attended. As a result, the observed association does not reflect the true causal effect of attending events. Intervening to make someone attend does not guarantee success, since the failures are not represented. The claim is invalid under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A study finds that people who attend many social events tend to have higher incomes. The analysis is conducted only among individuals who are members of exclusive clubs.
claim: Attending many social events causes people to have higher incomes.
label: NO

Z: Selection on club membership creates a collider between social activity and income
Club membership is influenced by both social activity and income

causal_structure: Both attending social events (X) and having a higher income (Y) increase the likelihood of being a club member (collider); conditioning on club membership opens a non-causal path between X and Y, so do(X) would not affect Y as observed.
key_insight: Conditioning on a collider (club membership) creates a spurious association between social activity and income.
hidden_timestamp: Was club membership determined before or after measuring social event attendance and income?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If club membership is determined before both variables, the observed association may be purely due to collider bias.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If club membership is not conditioned on, the association between social events and income may disappear.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here: the observed association is due to collider bias from conditioning on club membership, not a true effect of attending social events on income.
gold_rationale: This is a classic collider bias scenario: both attending social events and having higher income make club membership more likely. By restricting analysis to club members, a spurious association is induced between X and Y, even if there is no causal effect. Intervening to make someone attend more social events (do(X)) would not necessarily increase their income, since the association is an artifact of the selection process.

scenario: A study finds that people who start a new gym membership in January tend to live longer than those who join later in the year. The analysis only includes people who maintained their membership for at least 12 months.
claim: Joining a gym in January causes people to live longer.
label: NO

Z: Selection based on survival during the first 12 months

causal_structure: The observed association is distorted because only those who survived (and kept their membership) for 12 months are included, creating a period during which the outcome (death) could not occur, thus biasing the results.
key_insight: Restricting analysis to survivors over a fixed period introduces immortal time bias, invalidating causal claims.
hidden_timestamp: Did any participants die or drop out within the first 12 months after joining, and were they excluded from the analysis?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If early deaths or dropouts were excluded, the association is biased and does not reflect a true causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If all joiners, including early deaths or dropouts, were analyzed, the association might better reflect causality.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because immortal time bias means the observed association does not reflect the effect of intervening to make someone join a gym in January.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because the analysis only includes people who survived and maintained their gym membership for 12 months, introducing immortal time bias. This artificially inflates the apparent benefit of joining in January, as those who died or dropped out early are systematically excluded. Therefore, the observed association cannot be interpreted as the causal effect of joining a gym in January.

scenario: A group of people with unusually high blood pressure is selected for a wellness program. After six months, their average blood pressure has decreased significantly.
claim: Participating in the wellness program caused the reduction in blood pressure.
label: NO
causal_structure: The observed decrease in blood pressure may be due to regression to the mean, since individuals with extreme initial values tend to have less extreme values on subsequent measurements, regardless of intervention.
key_insight: Selecting extreme cases can create the illusion of a causal effect due to statistical regression, not intervention.
hidden_timestamp: Were the reductions in blood pressure also observed in a comparable group not selected for extreme values?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If a similar reduction occurred in a non-participant group with high initial blood pressure, the program likely had no causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only program participants improved and not the comparable group, the program may have had an effect.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because regression to the mean, not the intervention itself, can explain the observed association under do(X).
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because the observed reduction in blood pressure may simply reflect regression to the mean: when individuals are selected for extreme values, their subsequent measurements tend to move closer to the average even without any intervention. This statistical artifact can create the false appearance of a causal effect when, in reality, the change would have occurred without the program. Without a proper control group, we cannot attribute the improvement to the program itself.

scenario: A study finds that neighborhoods with more public parks have lower average rates of obesity. The data is aggregated at the city level, comparing cities with varying numbers of parks.
claim: Having more public parks in a neighborhood causes lower obesity rates among its residents.
label: NO

X.name: Number of public parks in a neighborhood

Z: Ecological fallacy: city-level association may not hold at the neighborhood level
Unmeasured confounders such as socioeconomic status or urban planning policies

causal_structure: The observed association is at the city level, not the individual or neighborhood level; do(X) at the neighborhood level may not affect Y due to aggregation bias and confounding by city-wide factors.
key_insight: Associations found in aggregated data do not necessarily imply the same causal effect at finer (e.g., neighborhood) levels.
