key_insight: The strict filters don't cause dissatisfaction; the traveler's mindset does.
hidden_timestamp: Are perfectionist expectations present before travelers choose their hotel rating filters?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If perfectionist expectations exist before filter use, removing rating requirements will not improve satisfaction.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If perfectionist expectations do not exist, changing filter use might affect satisfaction, but this is not supported by the observed association.

wise_refusal: I cannot attribute a causal effect to removing rating requirements because perfectionist expectations confound the relationship; intervening on filter use alone will not change the underlying mindset that drives dissatisfaction.
gold_rationale: This is a classic confounding trap. Travelers with perfectionist expectations are more likely to use strict hotel rating filters and also more likely to be dissatisfied with their trips. The observed association does not imply that using strict filters causes dissatisfaction; rather, both are caused by the underlying personality trait. Intervening on filter use without addressing perfectionism will not affect satisfaction.

scenario: People who use fitness trackers report more frequent exercise-related injuries than non-users. These users also visit physical therapists more frequently.
claim: Using fitness trackers causes more exercise-related injuries
label: NO
causal_structure: High exercise activity (Z) leads people to both use fitness trackers (X) and experience more injuries (Y), creating a spurious association between X and Y due to selection bias.
key_insight: Highly active people self-select into tracker use and have more injury exposure.
hidden_timestamp: Are fitness tracker users more injury-prone because of their activity level, or does tracker use itself increase injury risk?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If high activity level is the true cause, intervening on tracker use alone will not affect injury rates.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If tracker use itself increases injury risk, then forcing tracker use would increase injuries even among less active people.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid: the observed association is explained by selection bias—highly active individuals both use trackers and are more likely to be injured, so intervening on tracker use does not imply a causal effect on injuries.
gold_rationale: This claim is invalid because it confuses correlation with causation due to selection bias. People who are highly active are more likely to use fitness trackers and also more likely to experience exercise-related injuries due to their increased exposure. The observed association does not imply that using a fitness tracker causes injuries; rather, both are consequences of high activity levels.

scenario: People who read health blogs daily report more frequent minor symptoms than non-readers. These readers also schedule more medical appointments.
claim: Reading health blogs daily causes more frequent minor symptoms
label: NO
causal_structure: Health anxiety (Z) causes both daily health blog reading (X) and frequent minor symptoms (Y); thus, the observed association is due to selection bias, not a causal effect of X on Y.
key_insight: Health-anxious people self-select into blog reading and hyper-report symptoms.
hidden_timestamp: Are the people who read health blogs daily already more health-anxious before they start reading, or does blog reading increase their anxiety and symptom reporting?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If people were already health-anxious before reading blogs, then reading blogs does not cause more frequent minor symptoms.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If reading blogs directly increased health anxiety and symptom reporting in previously non-anxious people, then the claim might be valid.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because selection bias (specifically self-selection by health-anxious individuals) explains the association: intervening to make someone read health blogs would not necessarily increase their symptom reporting unless they were already health-anxious.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because health anxiety drives both the exposure (daily health blog reading) and the outcome (frequent minor symptoms). This self-selection creates a spurious association: people who are already anxious about their health are more likely to read health blogs and to notice and report minor symptoms. Intervening to make a non-anxious person read health blogs would not necessarily increase their symptom reporting, so the observed association does not imply causation.

scenario: Athletes who train at 5 AM have better performance than afternoon trainers. An aspiring athlete decides to train at 5 AM to improve their results.
claim: Training at 5 AM causes better athletic performance
label: NO
causal_structure: Dedication or discipline (Z) causes both the choice to train at 5 AM (X) and superior athletic performance (Y), so intervening on X alone does not produce the observed effect.
key_insight: Changing the training time does not transfer the underlying dedication that drives performance.
hidden_timestamp: Does the aspiring athlete possess the same level of dedication and discipline as those who naturally choose to train at 5 AM?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the athlete has the same dedication as 5 AM trainers, performance may improve due to overall commitment.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the athlete lacks that dedication, simply training at 5 AM will not improve performance and may even be detrimental.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid: the observed association is due to confounding by dedication and discipline, not the training time itself. Intervening on training time without changing dedication does not guarantee improved performance.
gold_rationale: This is a classic confounding trap. The trait of dedication or discipline causes both early training and better performance. The observed association does not imply that changing training time alone will cause improved results. Without the underlying trait, the intervention (do(X)) does not produce the expected outcome.

scenario: Students who study before 6 AM achieve higher grades than evening studiers. An aspiring student decides to study at 5 AM to boost their GPA.
claim: Studying before 6 AM causes higher grades
label: NO
causal_structure: An underlying trait (academic discipline/GPA dedication, Z) causes both early morning studying (X) and higher academic grades (Y), so intervening on X alone does not affect Y unless Z is also changed.
key_insight: Mimicking the habit doesn't transfer the underlying trait.
hidden_timestamp: Does the student possess the same level of academic discipline and dedication as those who naturally study before 6 AM?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the student has the same underlying discipline as early risers, their grades may improve.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the student lacks the underlying discipline, simply studying earlier will not improve grades and may even harm performance.

wise_refusal: I cannot attribute a causal effect to studying before 6 AM because the observed association is confounded by academic discipline and dedication. Intervening on study time alone does not address the underlying trait driving both behaviors.
gold_rationale: This claim is invalid because it confuses correlation with causation due to confounding. Students who study before 6 AM tend to be more disciplined and dedicated, which leads to both their early study habits and higher grades. Simply changing study time without changing the underlying discipline will not produce the same academic results and may even be counterproductive.

scenario: Classrooms where students use fidget toys have lower test scores than quiet classrooms. The teacher bans fidget toys to improve performance.
claim: Fidget toys cause lower test scores
label: NO
causal_structure: A noisy or distracting classroom environment (Z) causes both increased fidget toy usage (X) and lower test scores (Y), making X and Y associated without X causing Y.
key_insight: Fidget toys are a response to a disruptive learning environment, not the cause of poor performance.
hidden_timestamp: Is the noisy/distracting classroom environment present before fidget toy usage and low test scores are observed?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the distracting environment is the root cause, banning fidget toys will not improve test scores and may make things worse.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If fidget toys themselves directly cause distraction, banning them could improve test scores.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid: the observed association is confounded by the classroom environment. Intervening on fidget toy usage (do(X)) does not address the underlying cause (Z).
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because the association between fidget toy usage and low test scores is confounded by the noisy or distracting classroom environment. Students use fidget toys as a coping mechanism in response to poor learning conditions, which also directly reduce test scores. Banning fidget toys does not address the root cause and may even worsen outcomes by removing a coping tool.

scenario: Workplaces where employees take frequent breaks have lower output than continuous work environments. The manager reduces break frequency to increase productivity.
claim: Frequent breaks cause lower workplace output
label: NO
causal_structure: Poor work environment (Z) causes both frequent breaks (X) and low output (Y), so the observed association between X and Y is confounded by Z.
key_insight: Frequent breaks are a response to stressful or unmotivating work conditions, not the cause of low output.
hidden_timestamp: Are frequent breaks being taken because of poor work environment conditions, or are they imposed independently?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If frequent breaks are a response to poor work environment conditions, reducing breaks will not improve output and may worsen it.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If frequent breaks are imposed regardless of work environment, then reducing them might affect output, but this is not supported by the observed association.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the observed association is confounded by poor work environment conditions. Intervening on break frequency without addressing the underlying environment will not necessarily increase output.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because poor work environment conditions cause both frequent break-taking (as a coping mechanism) and low output. The observed association between breaks and output is confounded by the work environment. Intervening to reduce breaks does not address the root cause and may even decrease productivity by removing a coping mechanism.

scenario: Homes where families use white noise machines have more sleep problems than quiet homes. A sleep consultant recommends removing white noise to improve sleep.
claim: White noise machines cause more sleep problems
label: NO
causal_structure: Noisy environment (Z) causes both white noise machine usage (X) and sleep problems (Y); X is a coping response, not a cause.
key_insight: White noise machines are a response to disruptive sleep environments, not the cause of sleep problems.
hidden_timestamp: Is the noisy sleep environment present before families start using white noise machines?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the noisy environment is present before white noise machine use, removing the machine will not improve sleep and may worsen it.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the environment is quiet and white noise is introduced, then removing it could potentially improve sleep, but this is not the observed scenario.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the observed association is confounded by the noisy sleep environment, which causes both white noise machine usage and sleep problems. Removing white noise does not address the root cause.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because it confuses a coping mechanism with a cause. Families use white noise machines in response to noisy sleep environments, which are the true cause of both increased machine usage and sleep problems. The association does not imply that white noise machines cause sleep problems; rather, both are effects of the underlying noise. Intervening on white noise machine usage without addressing the noisy environment will not improve sleep and may worsen it.

scenario: Gyms where members use workout apps have lower fitness gains than app-free gyms. The trainer bans apps to improve results.
claim: Workout apps cause lower fitness gains
label: NO
causal_structure: Poor gym training quality (Z) causes both increased workout app usage (X) and lower fitness gains (Y); the observed association is confounded by Z.
key_insight: Workout apps are a response to inadequate gym instruction, not the cause of poor fitness gains.
hidden_timestamp: Is poor gym training quality the reason members use workout apps, and does it also independently reduce fitness gains?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If poor gym training quality is the true cause, banning workout apps will not improve fitness gains and may make them worse.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If workout apps directly reduce fitness gains regardless of gym quality, banning them could improve results.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the association is confounded: poor gym training quality leads to both app usage and lower fitness gains. Intervening on app usage without addressing training quality will not improve outcomes.
gold_rationale: This is a classic confounding trap. Members use workout apps to compensate for poor gym training quality, which itself causes lower fitness gains. The observed association between app usage and lower gains is due to both being effects of poor training, not a direct causal effect of the apps. Banning apps does not address the root cause and may even worsen outcomes by removing a coping mechanism.

scenario: Patients who receive physical therapy have worse mobility than those who don't. A doctor recommends stopping therapy to improve mobility.
claim: Physical therapy causes worse mobility
label: NO
causal_structure: Pre-existing mobility problems (Z) cause both referral to physical therapy (X) and poor mobility outcomes (Y), so the observed association between therapy and mobility is confounded by indication.
key_insight: Therapy is prescribed for patients with existing mobility issues, not at random.
hidden_timestamp: Did the patients have poor mobility before starting physical therapy, or did their mobility worsen after therapy began?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If patients had poor mobility before starting therapy, stopping therapy would not improve their mobility.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If therapy itself caused a decline in mobility, then stopping therapy might improve mobility, but this is not supported by the observed selection process.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because of selection bias (indication bias): patients receive physical therapy due to pre-existing mobility problems, so intervening to stop therapy would not improve mobility and may worsen it.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because it confuses correlation due to selection bias with causation. Physical therapy is given to those with poor mobility, so the worse mobility among therapy recipients reflects their underlying condition, not a harmful effect of therapy. Stopping therapy would not improve mobility, as the association is driven by indication bias.

scenario: Employees who receive performance coaching have lower productivity than those who don't. A manager recommends ending coaching to boost output.
claim: Performance coaching causes lower productivity
label: NO
causal_structure: Pre-existing productivity problems (Z) cause both lower productivity (Y) and assignment to coaching (X), so the observed association between coaching and productivity is confounded by Z.
key_insight: Coaching is assigned to employees with existing performance issues.
hidden_timestamp: Were employees assigned to coaching because of prior low productivity, or was coaching randomly assigned regardless of prior performance?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If coaching is assigned due to prior low productivity, ending coaching will not improve productivity and may make it worse.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If coaching is randomly assigned, then we could evaluate its true effect on productivity.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here due to selection bias (indication bias): the observed association does not reflect the effect of intervening on coaching assignment, because coaching is given to those with pre-existing productivity problems.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because it confuses correlation with causation. Employees are selected for coaching based on poor productivity, so the lower productivity is not caused by coaching but is the reason for receiving it. This is selection bias (indication bias): the group receiving coaching is systematically different from those who do not, and intervening to end coaching would not remove the underlying productivity issues.

scenario: Athletes who receive specialized training have worse performance than those who don't. A coach recommends stopping training to improve results.
claim: Specialized training causes worse athletic performance
label: NO
causal_structure: Pre-existing performance problems (Z) cause both assignment to specialized training (X) and poor athletic performance (Y); thus, the observed association between X and Y is confounded by Z.
key_insight: Specialized training is assigned to athletes with existing performance issues, not at random.
hidden_timestamp: Did the athletes who received specialized training already have worse performance before the training was assigned?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If athletes with specialized training already had worse performance before training, then the observed association is due to selection bias, not a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If athletes were randomly assigned to specialized training regardless of prior performance, then the observed association could reflect a causal effect.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here due to selection bias (indication bias): the worse performance is likely the reason for receiving specialized training, not the result. Intervening to stop training would not improve performance.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because specialized training is given to athletes who already have performance problems. This selection process creates an association between training and poor performance that does not reflect a causal effect of training. The observed relationship is confounded by pre-existing performance issues, so intervening on training would not necessarily improve results.

scenario: Drivers who take defensive driving courses have more accidents than those who don't. An insurance company recommends avoiding courses to reduce accidents.
claim: Defensive driving courses cause more accidents
label: NO
causal_structure: Drivers with poor driving records (Z) are more likely to enroll in defensive driving courses (X) and also more likely to have more accidents (Y), creating a spurious association between X and Y.
key_insight: Drivers who take defensive driving courses are selected due to existing safety issues, not because courses cause accidents.
hidden_timestamp: Were drivers assigned to courses randomly, or did only those with prior accidents enroll?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If drivers were randomly assigned to courses, accident rates would reflect the true effect of the course.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only drivers with poor records enrolled, the observed association is due to selection bias, not a causal effect.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here due to selection bias (indication bias): drivers with more accidents are more likely to take defensive driving courses, so the observed association does not reflect the effect of do(X).
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because it confuses correlation with causation due to selection bias. Defensive driving courses are typically taken by drivers with poor records or accident histories, who are at higher risk regardless of the course. The higher accident rate among course-takers reflects their underlying risk, not a harmful effect of the course. Only a randomized intervention could reveal the true causal effect.

scenario: Users of calorie tracking apps report more disordered eating than non-users. You delete the app to improve your relationship with food.
claim: Calorie tracking apps cause disordered eating
label: NO

Z: Pre-existing food anxiety / Eating disorder tendency

causal_structure: Pre-existing food anxiety (Z) increases the likelihood of using calorie tracking apps (X), and app usage (X) can further worsen food anxiety (Z), creating a feedback loop that also affects disordered eating patterns (Y). Thus, the observed association does not isolate the effect of do(X) due to the feedback between X and Z.
key_insight: Feedback loops between app usage and food anxiety confound causal inference from observational data.
hidden_timestamp: Did the onset of disordered eating occur before or after starting to use the calorie tracking app?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If disordered eating began before using the app, deleting the app may not improve the relationship with food.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If disordered eating began after using the app, deleting the app could potentially help, but the feedback loop complicates causal attribution.

wise_refusal: I cannot attribute a causal effect to calorie tracking app usage because the observed association is confounded by a feedback loop with pre-existing food anxiety; intervention on app usage alone does not isolate its effect.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid under intervention reasoning because people with pre-existing food anxiety or eating disorder tendencies are more likely to use calorie tracking apps, and app usage can further worsen anxiety, creating a feedback loop. This mutual influence means that simply intervening on app usage (do(X)) does not cleanly separate the effect of the app from the underlying anxiety. The observed association is therefore not sufficient to justify a causal claim.

scenario: Users of social media tracking apps report higher levels of social anxiety than non-users. You consider deleting the app to improve your social well-being.
claim: Social media tracking apps cause social anxiety
label: NO

Z: Feedback loop between anxiety and app engagement

causal_structure: Social insecurity (Z) increases the likelihood of using tracking apps (X), and app usage (X) can further worsen social anxiety (Y), creating a feedback loop. The association between X and Y does not imply that do(X) (deleting the app) will reduce Y, since Z may persist and drive anxiety regardless of X.
key_insight: Feedback loops can make it misleading to infer that intervening on one variable will break the cycle.
hidden_timestamp: Does deleting the app remove the influence of social insecurity, or does social insecurity persist and continue to affect anxiety after the intervention?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If deleting the app also addresses the underlying social insecurity, social anxiety may decrease.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If social insecurity persists after deleting the app, social anxiety is likely to remain unchanged.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution fails because the feedback loop means intervening on app usage alone does not guarantee a change in anxiety; the underlying insecurity may still drive anxiety regardless of the intervention.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid under intervention reasoning because the observed association is shaped by a feedback loop: social insecurity leads to app usage and is also worsened by it. Removing the app (do(X)) does not necessarily break the cycle if the root cause (Z) remains, so the direct causal effect from app usage to anxiety cannot be inferred from the association.

scenario: Owners of expensive bicycles have fewer accidents than cheap bike owners. You buy an expensive bike to avoid accidents.
claim: Expensive bicycles cause fewer accidents
label: NO
causal_structure: Careful riding behavior (Z) confounds the relationship: people who buy expensive bikes (X) are more likely to ride carefully (Z), and careful riding reduces accident rate (Y). The observed association between X and Y is not causal.
key_insight: The bike's cost doesn't prevent accidents; the owner's protective behavior does.
hidden_timestamp: Would buying an expensive bike actually change your riding behavior to be more careful, or is carefulness independent of bike cost for you?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If buying an expensive bike makes you ride more carefully, your accident rate may decrease.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If your riding behavior doesn't change with bike cost, your accident rate will likely stay the same.

wise_refusal: I cannot attribute a causal effect to buying an expensive bike because the observed association is confounded by careful riding behavior; intervention on bike cost alone does not guarantee a change in accident rate.
gold_rationale: This claim is invalid because it confuses correlation with causation due to confounding. Owners of expensive bicycles tend to ride more carefully to protect their investment, and this carefulness—not the bike's cost—reduces accident risk. Simply buying an expensive bike does not ensure safer riding unless it also changes your behavior. The causal effect is not justified under intervention reasoning.

scenario: Users of premium smartphones have fewer security breaches than basic phone users. You buy a premium phone to avoid hacking.
claim: Premium smartphones cause fewer security breaches
label: NO
causal_structure: Owning a premium smartphone is associated with fewer security breaches, but this association may be confounded by user behavior or technical literacy: users who buy premium phones may also be more security-conscious or tech-savvy, which independently reduces breach risk.
key_insight: The observed association may be due to confounding by user characteristics, not the phone itself.
hidden_timestamp: Are premium phone users inherently more security-conscious or technically skilled than basic phone users?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If premium phone users are more security-conscious, buying a premium phone alone may not reduce breaches.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If all users have similar security habits, premium phones' features could reduce breaches.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid: the observed association may be confounded by user behavior or technical literacy, so intervening on phone ownership (do(X)) does not guarantee a reduction in security breaches.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because the observed association between premium smartphone ownership and fewer security breaches may be due to confounding factors such as user security awareness or technical skill. People who choose premium phones might also be more likely to follow best security practices, update their devices, or avoid risky behavior, which independently reduces breach risk. Therefore, simply buying a premium phone does not guarantee fewer breaches unless these confounders are addressed.

scenario: Owners of luxury homes have fewer break-ins than basic home owners. You buy a luxury home to avoid burglary.
claim: Luxury homes cause fewer break-ins
label: NO
causal_structure: Neighborhood security and built-in security features (Z) both influence the likelihood of owning a luxury home (X) and the frequency of break-ins (Y), confounding the observed association.
key_insight: The observed association between luxury home ownership and fewer break-ins is confounded by underlying security features and neighborhood safety.
hidden_timestamp: Are luxury homes truly the cause of fewer break-ins, or do safer neighborhoods and better security features explain both luxury home ownership and lower break-in rates?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If luxury home ownership is randomly assigned, break-in rates may not decrease unless security features and neighborhood safety are also improved.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If luxury home ownership is associated with better security and safer neighborhoods, the observed reduction in break-ins is due to these confounders, not the ownership itself.

wise_refusal: I cannot attribute a causal effect to luxury home ownership alone because the observed association is confounded by built-in security features and neighborhood safety, which influence both home type and break-in frequency.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid under intervention reasoning because the observed association between luxury home ownership and fewer break-ins is confounded by factors like built-in security features and safer neighborhoods. These confounders influence both the likelihood of owning a luxury home and the risk of break-ins. Intervening to own a luxury home without also changing these confounding factors does not guarantee a reduction in break-ins. Therefore, the causal claim does not hold.

scenario: Users who purchase premium software tend to have fewer computer viruses than those who use free software. You consider buying premium software to avoid malware, based on this observation.
claim: Premium software causes fewer computer viruses
label: NO
causal_structure: Security-conscious users are more likely to buy premium software and also practice safer computer habits, which independently lower virus risk. The observed association is confounded by these user characteristics, so intervening on software choice alone does not isolate the causal effect.
key_insight: Confounding user behavior means buying premium software may not itself reduce viruses unless user habits are also changed.
hidden_timestamp: Do premium software users already engage in safer computer practices regardless of the software they use?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If premium software users are already more security-conscious and use other protective measures, then simply buying premium software will not necessarily reduce your virus risk.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If premium software users do not differ in security habits from free software users, then buying premium software could directly reduce your virus risk.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because confounding by user security habits means the observed association does not reflect the effect of intervening to buy premium software.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because the lower virus frequency among premium software users may be due to their greater security-consciousness and use of additional protective measures, not the software itself. These confounding factors mean that intervening to buy premium software does not guarantee a reduction in viruses unless user habits are also addressed. The causal effect cannot be established without ruling out confounding.

scenario: Owners of expensive watches have fewer time management issues than cheap watch owners. You buy an expensive watch to improve punctuality.
claim: Expensive watches cause better time management
label: NO
causal_structure: High income and disciplined lifestyle (Z) enable both expensive watch ownership (X) and good time management (Y); X is a marker, not a cause.
key_insight: The watch doesn't improve time management; the owner's existing discipline does.
hidden_timestamp: Does the person have a disciplined lifestyle and high income before buying the expensive watch?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the person already has a disciplined lifestyle and high income, buying an expensive watch will not change their punctuality.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the person lacks discipline and high income, buying an expensive watch alone will not improve their time management.

wise_refusal: I cannot attribute a causal effect to buying an expensive watch because the observed association is confounded by pre-existing discipline and income; intervention on watch ownership does not change the underlying cause.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because it confuses correlation with causation. People with high incomes and disciplined lifestyles are both more likely to own expensive watches and to have good time management. Simply buying an expensive watch does not instill discipline or improve punctuality; the association is due to confounding, not a direct effect.

scenario: People returning from life coaching sessions report more life dissatisfaction than the general population. You cancel your sessions to improve satisfaction.
claim: Life coaching sessions cause life dissatisfaction
label: NO
causal_structure: Pre-existing dissatisfaction or crisis (Z) causes people to seek life coaching (X) and also directly lowers life satisfaction (Y), creating a spurious association between coaching and dissatisfaction.
key_insight: People who seek life coaching are already dissatisfied, so the observed association does not imply coaching causes dissatisfaction.
hidden_timestamp: Did the dissatisfaction exist before attending life coaching sessions, or did it arise after?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If dissatisfaction existed before coaching, canceling sessions will not address the underlying issue.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If dissatisfaction arose only after coaching, then coaching might be responsible, but this is not established by the observed association.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because selection bias (crisis selection) means those who attend coaching are already dissatisfied; intervening on coaching attendance does not address the underlying dissatisfaction.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid due to selection bias: people seek life coaching when they are already dissatisfied or in crisis. The higher dissatisfaction among coaching clients reflects pre-existing conditions, not an effect of coaching itself. The observed association does not justify a causal effect under intervention reasoning, as canceling sessions does not address the root cause of dissatisfaction.

scenario: People returning from support groups report higher emotional distress than the general population. You cancel your group membership to reduce distress.
claim: Support groups cause higher emotional distress
label: NO
causal_structure: Individuals experiencing emotional crises (Z) are more likely to attend support groups (X) and also have higher emotional distress (Y), creating a selection bias in the observed association between X and Y.
key_insight: Emotionally stable people rarely join support groups, so group members' distress is not caused by attendance.
hidden_timestamp: Did emotional distress precede support group attendance, or did it increase after joining?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If distress levels were already high before joining, support group attendance did not cause the distress.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If distress increased only after joining, then group attendance might be a cause, but this is not established by the observed association.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because selection bias (crisis selection) means people join support groups due to pre-existing distress, not because groups cause distress.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid due to selection bias: people join support groups when they are already experiencing high emotional distress or mental health crises. The higher distress observed among group members reflects pre-existing conditions, not an effect of group participation. Comparing support group members to the general population conflates help-seeking behavior with the underlying problems that motivated joining, so intervening on attendance would not reduce distress as claimed.

scenario: A college student observes that professors with exceptional research tend to be weaker teachers. They conclude that research excellence causes poor teaching. However, the student only observes professors who were hired by the university.
claim: Research excellence causes poor teaching
label: NO
causal_structure: Research excellence and teaching quality both affect the likelihood of being hired (the collider). Conditioning on hiring induces a spurious negative association between research and teaching among professors.
key_insight: Conditioning on hiring (a collider) creates a false negative correlation between research and teaching skills.
hidden_timestamp: Were all individuals, including those not hired, considered in the analysis, or only those who became professors?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If all candidates (hired and not hired) are considered, there may be no negative association between research and teaching.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only hired professors are considered, a spurious negative association appears due to collider bias.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because conditioning on hiring (a collider) induces a spurious association; this is a classic case of Berkson's Paradox (collider bias) at the intervention level.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because the observed negative association arises from conditioning on a collider—university hiring—which is influenced by both research excellence and teaching quality. Academics with both poor research and poor teaching are not hired and thus excluded from the observed group, creating an artificial negative correlation among those hired. Intervening on research excellence would not necessarily affect teaching quality in the general population.

scenario: A music producer observes that artists with exceptional vocal talent tend to write weaker lyrics. They conclude that vocal ability causes poor songwriting. However, the producer only works with artists who signed record deals.
claim: Vocal ability causes poor songwriting
label: NO
causal_structure: Vocal talent and lyric writing quality both influence the chance of signing a record deal (the collider). Conditioning on signed artists induces a spurious negative association between vocal talent and lyric writing quality, even if they are independent in the general population.
key_insight: Conditioning on record deal success (a collider) creates a false negative association between vocal talent and lyric writing quality.
hidden_timestamp: Did the producer observe all aspiring artists, or only those who signed record deals?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the producer observed all aspiring artists (not just signed ones), there may be no association between vocal talent and lyric writing quality.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the producer only observed signed artists, a spurious negative association appears due to conditioning on the collider (record deal).

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because conditioning on signing a record deal (a collider) induces a spurious association between vocal talent and lyric writing quality. This is an example of Berkson's Paradox (collider bias) at the intervention level.
gold_rationale: The producer's conclusion falls into the collider bias trap, specifically Berkson's Paradox. By only considering artists who signed record deals, they condition on a variable influenced by both vocal talent and lyric writing quality. Artists with both poor vocals and poor lyrics are excluded, artificially creating a negative association between the two skills among the observed group. This does not justify a causal claim under intervention reasoning.

scenario: New yoga students report a sharp increase in flexibility. Credit card data shows these students also purchased expensive yoga equipment this month.
claim: Starting yoga causes increased flexibility
label: NO
causal_structure: A common cause (equipment purchase) may drive both yoga practice and flexibility improvement, so intervening on yoga alone may not produce the observed effect.
key_insight: A parallel investment in flexibility (equipment) may confound the relationship between yoga and flexibility gains.
hidden_timestamp: Did the equipment purchase happen before flexibility improvements became visible?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the equipment purchase preceded flexibility improvements, the equipment investment may be driving both yoga practice and flexibility gains.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If yoga practice began before equipment purchase, yoga may have led to flexibility gains, which then motivated equipment purchases.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because a confounder (equipment purchase) may be responsible for both starting yoga and increased flexibility; intervention on yoga alone does not guarantee the observed outcome.
gold_rationale: This case demonstrates confounding: the purchase of expensive yoga equipment may reflect a broader commitment to flexibility improvement, which could independently drive both increased yoga practice and flexibility gains. Without establishing the temporal order or ruling out the confounder, we cannot attribute the flexibility improvement to yoga practice alone. Intervening on yoga (do(X)) would not necessarily produce the same outcome if the underlying commitment (Z) is the true cause.

scenario: New language learners at a certain class report rapid progress. Credit card data shows these learners also bought language learning software and books this month.
claim: Taking language classes causes rapid progress
label: NO

Z: Language learning software and books purchase

causal_structure: Purchasing language learning resources (Z) may reflect a broader commitment to language improvement, which drives both class attendance (X) and learning progress (Y); thus, Z is a confounder of the observed association between X and Y.
key_insight: A parallel investment in resources can confound the relationship between class attendance and learning progress.
hidden_timestamp: Did the software and book purchases happen before progress improvements became visible?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If resource purchases preceded noticeable learning gains, the comprehensive learning investment may be driving both class attendance and independent study progress.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If classes were attended before resource purchases, class success may have motivated additional resource investment, but this does not establish that class attendance alone caused rapid progress.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because resource purchases may be a confounder: both class attendance and rapid progress could be driven by a broader commitment to language learning, not by class attendance alone.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because it ignores confounding by resource purchases. Learners who buy language learning software and books may be more motivated or committed, leading them both to attend classes and to make rapid progress. Without accounting for this confounder, intervening on class attendance (do(X)) does not guarantee the same outcome as observed, since the underlying commitment (Z) is not controlled.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because premium equipment purchases may confound the relationship: both class attendance and skill improvement could be driven by a broader commitment to cooking, not by the classes themselves.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because the observed association between cooking class attendance and skill improvement may be confounded by the purchase of premium kitchen equipment, which reflects a broader commitment to culinary improvement. This commitment could independently cause both class attendance and skill gains, so intervening on class attendance alone (do(X)) would not necessarily produce the observed outcome unless the confounder is controlled.

scenario: Women who started new jobs showed increased stress levels. We also observe they stopped regular exercise routines.
claim: Starting new jobs causes increased stress levels
label: NO

Z: Life stage changes (e.g., marriage, moving, family changes)

causal_structure: Life stage changes (such as age, marriage, or moving) may cause both starting a new job and stopping exercise routines, which in turn affects stress levels. Thus, the observed association between starting a new job and increased stress may be confounded by these underlying life transitions.
key_insight: Apparent causal links may be driven by confounding life stage changes, not direct effects.
hidden_timestamp: Did exercise cessation occur before or after starting the new job?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If exercise cessation occurred after starting the new job, job demands may have eliminated exercise time, increasing stress.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If exercise cessation occurred before the new job, both changes may reflect broader life stage transitions rather than job-induced stress.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because life stage changes may confound the relationship: both starting a new job and stopping exercise routines could be effects of a common cause, not a direct causal chain. Without ruling out confounding, we cannot claim that intervening on job status would change stress levels.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because it ignores confounding by life stage transitions. Both starting a new job and stopping exercise routines may be driven by underlying changes such as age, marriage, or moving. Intervening to start a new job would not necessarily increase stress if the true cause is a broader life transition affecting both variables. This is a classic confounding trap.

gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because the observed association between moving and decreased social connections may be confounded by underlying life transitions (such as job or relationship changes) that drive both behaviors. Without establishing that moving itself, rather than the confounder, causes the reduction in social connections, the causal claim does not hold under intervention reasoning.

claim: Starting graduate programs causes decreased free time
label: NO
causal_structure: Students who are predisposed to stop hobbies (Z) may be more likely to start graduate programs (X) and also have less free time (Y), creating a confounding pathway. conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the program itself causes students to stop hobbies, then intervening to enroll them could reduce free time through this pathway.

gold_rationale: The claim is invalid under intervention reasoning because the observed reduction in free time may be due to confounding by students' predisposition to stop hobbies or other unmeasured factors. If students who start graduate programs are already inclined to give up hobbies, the association between program enrollment and free time does not reflect a true causal effect. Only by ruling out confounding can we justify the intervention claim.

scenario: Parents who had their first child showed increased sleep deprivation. We also observe that many stopped maintaining regular sleep schedules after the child's birth.
claim: Having a first child causes increased sleep deprivation.
label: NO

Z: Disruption of regular sleep schedules (potential mediator or confounder)

causal_structure: Having a first child (X) may lead to disruption of regular sleep schedules (Z), which then increases sleep deprivation (Y). However, if Z (sleep schedule disruption) existed before X, it could confound the association; if Z follows X, it acts as a mediator.
key_insight: Without knowing whether sleep schedule disruption precedes or follows childbirth, we cannot attribute a direct causal effect from X to Y.
hidden_timestamp: Did the disruption of regular sleep schedules begin before or only after the first child was born?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If sleep schedule disruption began only after the first child was born, mediation is likely and the pathway from X to Y is plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If sleep schedule disruption was already present before the first child was born, it may confound the association and undermine the causal claim.

wise_refusal: I must refuse to attribute a direct causal effect from having a first child to increased sleep deprivation, because the timing of sleep schedule disruption is unclear—without knowing if Z is a mediator or a confounder, intervention on X does not guarantee a change in Y.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid under intervention reasoning because the observed association could be explained either by mediation (if sleep schedule disruption follows childbirth) or confounding (if sleep schedule disruption predates childbirth). Without precise temporal information about Z, we cannot conclude that do(X) would change Y. Intervention-level causality requires ruling out confounding and establishing the mediation pathway.

scenario: Employees who received promotions showed increased work hours. We also observe they stopped participating in leisure activities.
claim: Receiving promotions causes increased work hours
label: NO
causal_structure: The observed association between receiving promotions and increased work hours may be due to mediation by stopping leisure activities, but without ruling out confounding factors (like pre-existing work ethic or ambition), intervening on promotions does not guarantee increased work hours.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If employees only increased work hours after the promotion and stopped leisure activities as a result, the promotion may be causally responsible.

gold_rationale: The claim is invalid under intervention reasoning because the observed increase in work hours among promoted employees could be explained by confounding factors such as pre-existing work habits or ambition, or by mediation through stopping leisure activities. Without ruling out these alternative explanations, we cannot conclude that intervening to give someone a promotion would necessarily increase their work hours.

scenario: Users of a language learning app report faster progress. These users also recently moved to a country where that language is spoken.
claim: Using a language learning app causes faster progress
label: NO
causal_structure: Moving to the target language country (Z) increases both the likelihood of using the app (X) and making faster language progress (Y), so the observed association between app usage and progress is confounded by immersion.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If progress started immediately after the move, immersion is likely the main driver, not the app.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the app was used and progress occurred before the move, the app may have contributed independently.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution to the app is invalid because moving to the country confounds the relationship: immersion drives both app usage and progress. Without intervention-level evidence, we cannot conclude do(X) would change Y.
gold_rationale: This case demonstrates confounding: moving to a country where the target language is spoken (Z) increases both the likelihood of using a language app (X) and making faster progress (Y). The observed association does not justify a causal claim because both X and Y are effects of Z. Intervening on app usage alone (do(X)) would not necessarily produce the same outcome as observed, since the immersion environment is the true driver.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If exercise increased only after starting to use the app and before joining the gym, the app may have played a larger role.

gold_rationale: This claim is invalid because joining a gym with a personal trainer is a confounder: it can lead to both increased use of a fitness tracking app and increased exercise levels. The observed association does not imply that using the app causes more exercise, since both may be effects of the same underlying cause (professional training environment). Intervention on app usage alone would not necessarily increase exercise if the true driver is the gym and trainer.

scenario: A survey of gym members finds that those who attend the gym regularly report better overall health than those who do not attend.
claim: Going to the gym causes better overall health.
label: NO

Z: Selection bias due to only surveying gym members
Healthier individuals more likely to join and attend gym

causal_structure: The observed association arises because the sample only includes gym members, who are more likely to be health-conscious or already healthy, so intervening to make someone attend the gym does not guarantee improved health in the general population.
key_insight: Selection bias can create spurious associations that do not generalize to causal effects under intervention.
hidden_timestamp: Were non-gym members or less healthy individuals included in the sample, or only current gym attendees?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If only gym members were surveyed, the association does not reflect a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the sample included both gym members and non-members randomly, the association could be more indicative of causality.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because selection bias means the observed association does not reflect the effect of intervening on gym attendance in the general population.
gold_rationale: This is a classic case of selection bias: the sample is restricted to gym members, who may already be healthier or more motivated than non-members. As a result, the observed association between gym attendance and health is confounded by the selection process. Intervening to make someone attend the gym would not necessarily produce the same health benefits observed in this biased sample. The causal claim fails because the study design does not support generalization to the effect of do(X) in the population.

scenario: A study finds that people who attend early morning yoga classes are more likely to report high energy levels throughout the day, but only includes individuals who are currently employed full-time.
claim: Attending early morning yoga classes causes people to have higher energy levels throughout the day.
label: NO

Y.name: High energy levels throughout the day

Z: Selection bias due to only including full-time employed individuals
Unmeasured differences in baseline energy or schedule flexibility

causal_structure: The observed association is distorted by only including individuals who are able to attend early morning yoga and maintain full-time employment, excluding those who may have dropped out due to low energy or incompatible schedules; thus, do(X) does not guarantee the same outcome in the general population.
key_insight: Restricting analysis to a 'surviving' subgroup can create misleading causal claims.
hidden_timestamp: Were individuals who could not sustain both early yoga and full-time work excluded from the study sample?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If only current full-time employees who attend yoga are included, the association may reflect survivorship bias, not a true causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If all individuals, including those who could not maintain both activities, were included, the observed effect might disappear or reverse.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because the intervention (do(X)) would not account for survivorship bias—excluding those unable to sustain both yoga and employment distorts the causal effect.
gold_rationale: This claim is invalid because the sample only includes individuals who are both employed full-time and attend early yoga, potentially excluding those who tried but could not continue due to low energy or other constraints. This survivorship bias means the observed association does not generalize: intervening to make everyone attend early yoga would include people who would not have 'survived' in the original sample, so the causal effect is not identified.

scenario: A survey finds that among people who attend late-night study groups, there is a higher rate of coffee consumption and also a higher rate of reported insomnia. The analysis only includes students who are present at the library after midnight.
claim: Drinking coffee caused these students to develop insomnia.
label: NO

Z: Selection on being present at the library after midnight (collider)

causal_structure: Both coffee consumption and insomnia independently increase the likelihood of being present at the library after midnight; conditioning on this collider induces a spurious association between coffee and insomnia that would not exist under do(coffee).
key_insight: Conditioning on a collider (late-night library attendance) creates a non-causal association between coffee drinking and insomnia.
hidden_timestamp: Were students included in the analysis only if they were present at the library after midnight?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If students are selected based on late-night library attendance, the association between coffee and insomnia is likely spurious due to collider bias.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If all students are included regardless of library attendance time, the observed association may reflect a genuine relationship or other biases.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because conditioning on late-night library attendance (a collider) induces a spurious association between coffee and insomnia; intervention on coffee consumption would not necessarily affect insomnia rates.
gold_rationale: This case exemplifies collider bias: both coffee drinking and insomnia make it more likely for a student to be present at the library after midnight. By restricting the analysis to this group, a non-causal association is induced between coffee and insomnia. Intervening to make a student drink coffee does not imply they will develop insomnia, because the observed association is an artifact of the selection process, not a causal effect.

scenario: A study finds that people who take daily vitamins tend to live longer than those who do not, but the analysis only includes individuals who survived at least five years after starting vitamins.
claim: Taking daily vitamins causes people to live longer.
label: NO

Z: Immortal time bias due to including only those who survived the initial period

causal_structure: The observed association is distorted because only individuals who survived the first five years after starting vitamins are included, creating a period during which death could not have occurred for the vitamin group (immortal time), so do(X) does not map to the observed effect.
key_insight: Survival-based inclusion criteria can create artificial associations that do not reflect true causal effects.
hidden_timestamp: Were deaths occurring before five years after starting vitamins excluded from the analysis?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If deaths before five years were excluded, the association is biased and does not reflect a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If all deaths were included regardless of timing, the association would be less biased and might better reflect causality.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because immortal time bias means the observed association does not represent the effect of intervening to take vitamins.
gold_rationale: Immortal time bias occurs when the exposure group is defined such that individuals must survive a certain period to be included, artificially inflating survival in the exposure group. Here, only those who survived at least five years after starting vitamins are analyzed, so the observed association cannot be interpreted causally: intervening to make someone take vitamins does not guarantee they survive the initial period. The claim fails under do(X) reasoning.

scenario: A group of people with very high blood pressure is selected for a study. After starting a new diet, their average blood pressure decreases significantly over the next month.
claim: Starting the new diet caused the reduction in blood pressure.
label: NO
causal_structure: The observed association is due to selecting individuals with extreme initial blood pressure values, who are likely to show improvement over time regardless of intervention, not because the diet caused the change.
key_insight: Changes in extreme measurements often occur naturally over time, independent of interventions.
hidden_timestamp: Was the reduction in blood pressure compared to a control group not starting the diet, or only to the initial extreme values?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If compared only to initial values, the reduction may be due to regression to the mean, not the diet.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If compared to a randomized control group, a causal effect could be more credible.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is refused because the observed reduction may be explained by regression to the mean, not by the intervention itself.
gold_rationale: This case illustrates regression to the mean: selecting individuals with extreme values (very high blood pressure) means that, on average, their follow-up measurements will be closer to the population mean, even without any intervention. Therefore, the observed reduction cannot be attributed to the diet without a proper control group. The intervention-level flaw is that do(X) (forcing the diet) does not account for the statistical artifact caused by the initial selection of extreme cases.

scenario: A study finds that neighborhoods with more public parks have lower average body weights. The analysis is conducted at the city level, comparing aggregate park density and average BMI across cities.
claim: Having more public parks in a neighborhood causes individuals living there to have lower body weight.
label: NO

X.name: Number of public parks in a neighborhood

Z: Ecological fallacy (aggregate data does not imply individual effect)
Unmeasured individual-level confounders (e.g., income, health behaviors)

causal_structure: The observed association is at the city level (aggregate), but the claim is about individuals; confounding factors at the individual level (like income or health consciousness) may drive both park placement and body weight, so intervening to add parks in a neighborhood does not guarantee lower body weight for individuals.
key_insight: Aggregate associations do not necessarily reflect individual-level causal effects.
hidden_timestamp: Do individuals who move to neighborhoods with more parks actually experience weight loss, or is the association only present at the aggregate (city) level?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If individuals who move to park-rich neighborhoods do not lose weight, the aggregate association is not causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If individuals do lose weight after moving to park-rich neighborhoods, there may be a causal effect, but this is not established by the aggregate data.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because the observed association is at the aggregate level and does not account for individual-level confounding; intervention on park number does not guarantee the same effect for individuals due to the ecological fallacy.
gold_rationale: This is a classic ecological fallacy: the association between park density and body weight is observed at the city level, but this does not mean that increasing parks in a specific neighborhood will reduce individual body weight. Individual-level confounders (like income, health awareness, or access to other resources) may explain both park placement and health outcomes. Without individual-level intervention data, we cannot infer that do(X) would change Y for individuals.

scenario: People who drink more coffee tend to report higher levels of alertness in the morning, according to a workplace survey.
claim: Drinking more coffee causes people to be more alert in the morning.
label: NO

Z: Morning chronotype (early riser vs. night owl)

causal_structure: Morning chronotype (Z) affects both coffee consumption (X) and morning alertness (Y), confounding the observed association; intervening on X without controlling for Z does not guarantee a causal effect on Y.
key_insight: A confounder can explain the association between coffee and alertness without a true causal effect.
hidden_timestamp: Is morning chronotype (early riser vs. night owl) distributed equally among coffee drinkers and non-drinkers?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If chronotype is not balanced, the observed association may be due to confounding, not causation.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If chronotype is balanced, the association could reflect a causal effect, but this is not established by the observational data.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the observed association may be fully explained by confounding due to morning chronotype; intervention on coffee consumption (do(X)) does not guarantee a change in alertness (Y) without addressing Z.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because individuals with different chronotypes may both consume more coffee and feel more alert in the morning, creating a spurious association. Without controlling for chronotype, we cannot infer that intervening on coffee consumption would affect alertness. This is a classic confounding trap.

scenario: A survey finds that people who drink more coffee tend to report higher productivity, but when the data is separated by age group, the association disappears or reverses.
claim: Drinking more coffee causes people to be more productive.
label: NO

Z: age group as a confounder leading to Simpson's paradox

causal_structure: Age group influences both coffee consumption and productivity; the observed association between coffee and productivity is confounded by age, and the direction of association reverses when stratifying by age.
key_insight: Simpson’s paradox can make a group-level association appear causal when it is actually driven by a lurking variable.
hidden_timestamp: Is the association between coffee and productivity consistent within each age group, or does it reverse when stratified?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the association reverses or disappears within each age group, then coffee consumption does not cause higher productivity.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the association holds within each age group, then a causal effect is more plausible, but this is not established in the scenario.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because Simpson’s paradox is present: the group-level association between coffee and productivity is confounded by age, so intervening to increase coffee consumption would not necessarily increase productivity.
gold_rationale: The observed association between coffee consumption and productivity is confounded by age group, which affects both variables. Simpson’s paradox means the overall association can be misleading, and the effect reverses or disappears when stratifying by age. Therefore, the claim that drinking more coffee causes higher productivity is invalid under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A survey finds that people who drink herbal tea daily report lower stress levels. The researchers suggest that drinking herbal tea causes reduced stress.
claim: Drinking herbal tea daily causes lower stress levels.
label: NO
causal_structure: Health-conscious individuals are more likely to both drink herbal tea daily (X) and engage in other stress-reducing behaviors that directly lower stress (Y), making health-consciousness (Z) a confounder; mediation is also possible if tea drinking is part of a broader relaxation routine.
key_insight: Confounding and mediation must be disentangled before inferring causality from observed associations.
hidden_timestamp: Did the observed reduction in stress occur only after starting daily herbal tea consumption, and were other health behaviors controlled for?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If stress reduction only occurred after starting herbal tea and other behaviors were controlled, a causal effect is possible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If stress levels were already low due to other health behaviors, the association is likely confounded and not causal.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid here because the observed association may be due to confounding by health-consciousness or mediation through other behaviors; intervention on tea drinking alone may not produce the same effect.
gold_rationale: The claim is invalid because health-consciousness (Z) can cause both increased herbal tea consumption (X) and lower stress (Y), confounding the association. Additionally, if tea drinking is part of a broader relaxation routine, mediation further complicates the causal interpretation. Without isolating the effect of herbal tea from these factors, intervening on X (do(X)) does not guarantee a change in Y.

scenario: People who regularly take painkillers are often observed to report higher levels of chronic pain in surveys.
claim: Taking painkillers causes people to develop chronic pain.
label: NO

Z: Temporal order: chronic pain may precede painkiller use
Reverse causation: people take painkillers because they already have pain

causal_structure: The observed association is likely due to people with chronic pain being more likely to take painkillers (Y → X), not because taking painkillers causes chronic pain (X → Y).
key_insight: Reverse causation means the outcome may drive the exposure, invalidating causal claims from association.
hidden_timestamp: Did the chronic pain begin before or after the person started regularly taking painkillers?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If chronic pain began before painkiller use, painkillers did not cause the pain.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If chronic pain began after starting painkillers, a causal effect is possible but not established by this observation.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the direction of causality is ambiguous; the observed association may reflect reverse causation rather than an effect of do(X).
gold_rationale: This is a classic case of reverse causation: people take painkillers because they already have chronic pain, not the other way around. Observing that painkiller users have more chronic pain does not mean that taking painkillers causes pain. Without clear temporal information, intervention on painkiller use (do(X)) does not guarantee a change in pain outcomes (Y).

scenario: A person notices that the more frequently they check their phone for notifications, the more anxious they feel throughout the day. They conclude that checking their phone more often causes their anxiety.
claim: Checking your phone more often causes increased anxiety.
label: NO

Z: feedback loop between anxiety and phone checking

causal_structure: There is a feedback loop where anxiety increases phone checking, and increased phone checking may further increase anxiety, making the observed association non-causal under intervention.
key_insight: Feedback loops can create associations that do not reflect the effect of intervening on X.
hidden_timestamp: Does increased phone checking precede anxiety, or does anxiety lead to more phone checking?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If increased phone checking happens before anxiety rises, intervening might increase anxiety.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If anxiety leads to more phone checking, intervening on phone checking alone may not affect anxiety.

wise_refusal: Refuse to attribute causality: the observed association may be due to a feedback loop, so intervening on phone checking does not necessarily change anxiety.
gold_rationale: The observed association can be explained by a feedback loop: anxiety may cause more frequent phone checking, which could in turn reinforce anxiety. Without separating the temporal order or breaking the feedback, we cannot infer that intervening to increase phone checking would cause more anxiety. The feedback loop trap means the association does not reflect a unidirectional causal effect.

scenario: A survey finds that people who regularly meditate are less likely to report high stress levels. The data was collected at a single point in time, with no information about when meditation started relative to stress levels.
claim: Regular meditation caused lower stress levels.
label: NO

Z: Unclear temporal order between meditation and stress

causal_structure: The observed association does not establish whether meditation preceded lower stress or vice versa; without temporal information, do(X) (forcing meditation) may not affect Y (stress) as claimed.
key_insight: Without knowing if meditation started before stress reduction, causal inference is invalid.
hidden_timestamp: Did regular meditation begin before the reduction in stress, or did people with lower stress start meditating afterward?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If meditation began before stress reduction, a causal effect is possible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If lower stress preceded meditation, the observed association is not causal.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the temporal order between meditation and stress reduction is unknown, violating the requirements for valid intervention reasoning.
gold_rationale: This is a classic case of temporal ambiguity: the data do not reveal whether meditation preceded lower stress or if people with lower stress are more likely to meditate. Without establishing that X (meditation) occurs before Y (lower stress), we cannot infer that intervening to increase meditation would reduce stress. The observed association may be due to reverse causation or other factors, so the causal claim is invalid.

scenario: A survey asks people how many hours they sleep each night and how tired they feel during the day. The results show that people who report fewer hours of sleep also report feeling more tired.
claim: Getting fewer hours of sleep causes people to feel more tired during the day.
label: NO

X.name: Number of hours of sleep reported

Z: Measurement error in self-reported sleep duration

causal_structure: Both X and Y are subject to self-report measurement error, which can induce a spurious association that does not reflect the true causal effect of actual sleep duration on tiredness; intervening on reported hours does not guarantee a change in true sleep or tiredness.
key_insight: Measurement error in self-reported variables can create misleading associations that do not reflect true causal effects.
hidden_timestamp: Are the reported hours of sleep and tiredness accurate reflections of actual sleep duration and true tiredness, or are they biased by self-reporting errors?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If self-reports are accurate, intervening to increase true sleep duration could reduce tiredness.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If self-reports are inaccurate, intervening on reported hours may not affect true tiredness at all.

wise_refusal: We cannot attribute a causal effect from reported sleep hours to tiredness because measurement error in self-reported data breaks the validity of the intervention; do(X) does not correspond to changing true sleep.
gold_rationale: The observed association between reported sleep hours and tiredness may be entirely due to measurement error in self-reporting. People may over- or under-estimate both variables, and these errors can correlate, creating a spurious association. Intervening on the number of hours someone reports sleeping does not necessarily change their actual sleep or how tired they truly are. Thus, the causal claim is invalid under intervention reasoning.

scenario: A survey asks people how often they forget their keys and whether they feel stressed. People who report high stress also report forgetting their keys more often.
claim: Feeling stressed causes people to forget their keys more often.
label: NO
causal_structure: Both stress and key-forgetting are self-reported, and stressed individuals may recall or report their memory lapses differently, creating a spurious association that does not reflect the effect of actually intervening on stress.
key_insight: Recall bias in self-reported data can create false causal links.
hidden_timestamp: Did participants' stress levels affect their ability to accurately recall or report forgetting their keys, or did stress actually increase forgetfulness?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If stress only affects recall/reporting, intervening to increase stress would not increase actual key-forgetting.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If stress truly increases forgetfulness, intervening on stress would increase key-forgetting.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because recall bias in self-reported data means that intervening on stress may not change actual key-forgetting, only reported rates.
gold_rationale: The observed association may be due to recall bias: stressed individuals might be more likely to remember or report forgetting their keys, regardless of their actual behavior. Thus, intervening to increase stress would not necessarily increase the true rate of forgetting keys, invalidating the causal claim.

scenario: People who use noise-cancelling headphones at work are observed to report lower stress levels. It is claimed that using noise-cancelling headphones causes reduced stress for all workers.
claim: Using noise-cancelling headphones causes reduced stress.
label: NO

Z: the headphones may not actually reduce stress for all users

causal_structure: The observed association may be due to a subgroup for whom the headphones are effective, but the mechanism (blocking noise) may not work for all workers, or stress may be caused by factors unrelated to noise.
key_insight: A broken or incomplete mechanism invalidates the causal claim even if an association is observed.
hidden_timestamp: Do the headphones actually block the stress-inducing noise for all users, or are there other sources of stress unaffected by the intervention?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the headphones block all relevant noise, stress may decrease.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If stress is caused by other factors, or the headphones do not block the noise, stress will not decrease.

wise_refusal: Causal attribution is invalid because the mechanism connecting headphone use to stress reduction may not function as assumed under intervention; do(X) does not guarantee Y.
