But they also began traveling the same week and used the phone less, and it is unclear whether battery life improved immediately after enabling the feature or only after the behavior change.
claim: Enabling battery-saver mode caused the phone to last longer between charges.
label: NO

Z: Usage changes due to travel (screen time, GPS, video calls)
Network conditions (poor reception increases battery drain)
App updates or background process changes around the same time

causal_structure: Battery life changes depend on both X and concurrent time-varying factors; unclear ordering and co-occurring changes confound attribution.
key_insight: If other changes happened around the same time, you need clear timing and control to claim causality.
hidden_timestamp: Did battery life improve immediately after enabling battery-saver, before any usage changes occurred?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If phone usage and conditions remained comparable and battery life improved right after enabling the mode, the mode could be the cause.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If usage or conditions changed at the same time and the timing of improvement isn't tied to enabling the mode, the longer battery life cannot be attributed to the mode.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude battery-saver mode caused longer battery life because other time-varying factors changed and the timing of improvement isn't clear.
gold_rationale: Temporal ambiguity with concurrent behavior changes makes before/after causal claims unreliable. This case demonstrates a clear causal reasoning pattern that requires careful analysis of the underlying mechanisms.

scenario: A person starts drinking chamomile tea nightly (X) and later reports better sleep quality (Y). But the timeline is vague: they also changed work shifts that month, and it's unclear whether sleep improved after starting tea or after the schedule stabilized.
claim: Drinking chamomile tea nightly caused sleep quality to improve.
label: NO

Z: Stress level changes across the month
Other sleep hygiene changes (screen time, exercise)

causal_structure: The outcome may have improved due to shift stabilization or stress reduction; without clear temporal ordering relative to X, causality is unclear.
key_insight: A clear intervention start and outcome trajectory are necessary to establish temporal precedence.
hidden_timestamp: Did sleep quality improve only after the first nights of chamomile tea, before the work-shift effects resolved?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If sleep was consistently poor before tea and improved immediately after starting tea while work shifts and other factors stayed the same, tea could plausibly help.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If sleep improved after the schedule stabilized or alongside other changes and timing is unclear, the improvement cannot be attributed to tea.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude chamomile tea caused better sleep because the timeline is unclear and major schedule changes occurred around the same time.
gold_rationale: Temporal ambiguity prevents attributing changes to the intervention instead of coincident time-varying factors.

scenario: People who adopted a new low-sugar diet (X) are surveyed six months later about how many sugary snacks they ate before the diet and how many they eat now (Y). Diet adopters report a large reduction and claim the diet program caused it. However, participants may misremember their prior snack frequency or report what they think is socially desirable, and the outcome is entirely based on recall.
claim: The low-sugar diet program caused people to eat fewer sugary snacks.
label: NO

Y.name: Change in sugary snack consumption (self-reported by recall)

Z: Biased recall of pre-diet snack frequency
Social desirability bias in self-reported current snacks

causal_structure: Exposure status affects how participants remember and report past behavior, creating differential recall that can mimic an effect.
key_insight: When outcomes rely on memory of prior behavior, exposure can bias reporting, producing spurious before/after differences.
hidden_timestamp: Were pre-program snack levels measured prospectively (at baseline) or reconstructed later from memory after joining the program?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If baseline snack consumption was recorded before program adoption (e.g., food logs) and post-adoption consumption was measured similarly, a true reduction could support causality.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If participants reconstructed pre-diet snack intake from memory after adopting the diet, recall and desirability biases can explain the reported reduction without a causal effect.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude the program caused fewer snacks because the key outcome depends on retrospective recall, which can differ by program participation.
gold_rationale: Recall bias can create apparent improvements when participants misremember or selectively report past behavior after an intervention.

scenario: After completing a safety training course (X), employees are asked to recall how often they violated safety protocols in the months before training and how often they violate them now (Y). Trainees report fewer past violations and fewer current violations, and management concludes training caused safer behavior. But trainees may underreport past behavior or reshape memories to align with training expectations.
claim: Safety training caused employees to violate protocols less often.
label: NO

Y.name: Change in protocol violations (self-reported by recall)

Z: Post-training reinterpretation of what counts as a 'violation'
Underreporting of past violations due to social desirability

causal_structure: Training changes salience and reporting norms, biasing retrospective reports of past and current violations.
key_insight: If the outcome depends on participants remembering and admitting past behavior, the intervention can change reporting rather than behavior.
hidden_timestamp: Were protocol violations measured objectively (e.g., audits) before and after training, or only via retrospective self-report after training?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If independent audits recorded violations before and after training and violations decreased among trained employees compared to untrained controls, training could have a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If changes are based on trainees' retrospective self-reports, recall and desirability biases can explain the apparent reduction.

wise_refusal: We can't attribute fewer violations to training because the evidence relies on retrospective self-report that can be biased by training participation.
gold_rationale: Recall bias and shifting definitions can create spurious improvements in self-reported behavior following an intervention.

scenario: Parents whose children joined a new after-school sports program (X) are later asked to recall how many hours their child exercised per week before the program and how many hours they exercise now (Y). Parents report a large increase and conclude the program caused more exercise. But parents may overestimate baseline inactivity or selectively remember details after committing to the program.
claim: The after-school sports program caused children to exercise more each week.
label: NO

Z: Parents' biased recall of pre-program activity levels
Social desirability in reporting children's activity
Seasonal changes in outdoor play opportunities

causal_structure: Program participation influences memory and reporting of baseline activity, confounding before/after comparisons based on recall.
key_insight: Retrospective baseline measures can be systematically biased after an intervention.
hidden_timestamp: Was baseline exercise recorded before enrollment (e.g., activity tracker logs) or reconstructed later from parents' memory?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If baseline activity was measured prospectively (e.g., tracker data) and post-enrollment activity increased relative to comparable non-enrolled children, the program could have a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If baseline was recalled after enrollment, biased memory and desirability can inflate the apparent increase without a true causal effect.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude the program caused more exercise because the key comparison relies on parents recalling pre-program activity, which can be biased after enrollment.
gold_rationale: Recall bias can distort baseline measures and create spurious pre/post differences. This case demonstrates a clear causal reasoning pattern that requires careful analysis of the underlying mechanisms.

scenario: People who started a mindfulness app (X) are surveyed months later and asked to recall how often they felt anxious before starting and how often they feel anxious now (Y). Users report a big drop and claim the app reduced anxiety. But recall of prior anxiety can be distorted, and people who paid for the app may report improvements consistent with expectations.
claim: Using the mindfulness app caused anxiety to decrease.
label: NO

X.name: Starting regular use of a mindfulness app

Y.name: Change in anxiety frequency (self-reported by recall)

Z: Distorted recall of pre-app anxiety levels
Concurrent life changes (job stress, therapy, sleep) over months

causal_structure: App adoption affects recall and reporting of baseline anxiety, and long time gaps allow other changes to influence outcomes.
key_insight: Without prospectively measured baseline, improvements may reflect biased memory and expectations rather than causal effects.
hidden_timestamp: Was anxiety measured before app use with the same instrument, or only reconstructed later from memory after app adoption?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If anxiety was measured prospectively pre-app and post-app using the same validated scale, and users improve more than comparable non-users, a causal effect is plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If baseline anxiety is based on retrospective recall after months of app use, recall and expectation biases can explain the reported drop.

wise_refusal: We can't attribute decreased anxiety to the app because the comparison relies on retrospective recall and may reflect reporting biases and other changes over time.
gold_rationale: Recall bias and expectancy effects can create apparent improvements in self-reported mental health outcomes post-intervention.

scenario: A team compares employees who use a new focus-music playlist during work (X) to those who do not. Playlist users appear to complete more tasks per day (Y). But people who choose to use the playlist tend to have more demanding roles and higher baseline conscientiousness, which also increases task completion.
claim: Using the focus-music playlist causes employees to complete more tasks per day.
label: NO

X.name: Using the focus-music playlist while working

Z: Role demands and task assignment differences

causal_structure: A common cause (motivation/role demands) influences both choosing the playlist and higher productivity, confounding the observed association.
key_insight: Self-selection into an exposure can reflect underlying traits that also affect the outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Were employees randomly assigned to use the playlist, or did motivated/high-performing employees disproportionately choose it?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If employees were randomly assigned to use the playlist (or matched on role and baseline productivity) and still completed more tasks, the playlist could plausibly increase productivity.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If playlist use is self-selected and correlated with motivation or role demands, the observed difference can be explained by confounding rather than a causal effect.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude the playlist caused higher productivity because employees who choose it may already be more motivated or have different roles.
gold_rationale: Confounding by self-selection can generate associations that are not causal. This case demonstrates a clear causal reasoning pattern that requires careful analysis of the underlying mechanisms.

scenario: People who buy a meal-prep subscription (X) have lower average BMI after six months (Y) than those who do not. The company claims the subscription causes weight loss. However, people who choose meal-prep tend to be more health-conscious and already dieting, which affects both purchasing and weight outcomes.
claim: Buying the meal-prep subscription causes people to lose weight.
label: NO

Z: Baseline health consciousness and dieting intent
Baseline BMI and prior weight trajectory

causal_structure: Health motivation influences both the decision to subscribe and the likelihood of losing weight, creating confounding.
key_insight: When exposure is chosen, underlying preferences and behaviors can drive both exposure and outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Were subscribers already on a weight-loss trajectory or more health-motivated before subscribing compared to non-subscribers?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If subscription access were randomly assigned (or carefully adjusted for baseline motivation, diet, and exercise) and subscribers still lose more weight, a causal effect is plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If subscribers are systematically more health-conscious or already dieting, the lower BMI can be explained by confounding rather than the subscription causing weight loss.

wise_refusal: We can't attribute weight loss to the meal-prep subscription because subscribers may differ in motivation and lifestyle from non-subscribers.
gold_rationale: Confounding by baseline motivation and behaviors can explain the observed differences in BMI. This case demonstrates a clear causal reasoning pattern that requires careful analysis of the underlying mechanisms.

scenario: A neighborhood watch group installs more outdoor lighting on their street (X). After six months, reported theft incidents (Y) are lower than on nearby streets without the lighting. The group claims the lighting reduced theft. However, the street that installed lighting also has higher household income and more residents working from home, which can reduce theft risk independently of lighting.
claim: Installing outdoor lighting reduced theft incidents on the street.
label: NO

Y.name: Number of theft incidents reported over six months

Z: Household income and property security features
Police patrol frequency and reporting behavior

causal_structure: Neighborhood characteristics influence both installing lighting and theft risk, confounding the association between lighting and theft reduction.
key_insight: Community-level interventions are often correlated with baseline safety and resources that also affect outcomes.
hidden_timestamp: Did the street differ from comparison streets in baseline wealth, security practices, or resident presence before installing lighting?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If lighting were installed in a randomized rollout (or compared with closely matched streets on baseline safety and resources) and theft drops more where lighting is added, causality is plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the lighting street is wealthier or more monitored than others, those confounders can explain lower theft without lighting being the cause.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude lighting caused fewer thefts because streets that choose lighting may already be safer or have different resources and monitoring.
gold_rationale: Confounding by neighborhood resources and baseline safety can produce apparent intervention effects.

scenario: A clinic gives patients with diabetes a new continuous glucose monitor (CGM) system (X). Three months later, the clinic reports better average glucose control (Y) among CGM users than non-users. However, CGM users have frequent measurements that detect short spikes and allow timely corrections, while non-users have infrequent finger-stick logs that miss spikes and are sometimes back-filled, making outcomes not directly comparable.
claim: Providing CGMs caused patients to have better glucose control over three months.
label: NO

X.name: Receiving a continuous glucose monitor system

Z: Different measurement frequency and capture of glucose spikes (CGM vs finger-stick logs)
Selective logging or back-filling of finger-stick measurements
Baseline self-management motivation differences between adopters and non-adopters

causal_structure: Exposure changes the measurement instrument and sampling process for Y, creating differential measurement error and comparability issues.
key_insight: If the exposure changes how the outcome is measured, observed differences may be measurement artifacts rather than true outcome changes.
hidden_timestamp: Are glucose outcomes computed from the same measurement method, frequency, and rules for CGM users and non-users?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If both groups' glucose control is assessed using the same standardized measurement protocol (e.g., lab A1c) and CGM users still improve more, a causal effect is plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If CGM users are measured continuously while non-users rely on sparse logs, differences may reflect measurement bias and non-comparable metrics rather than CGMs causing better control.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude CGMs caused better control because the outcome is measured differently across groups, which can create spurious differences.
gold_rationale: Differential measurement by exposure status can mimic treatment effects even without true physiological differences.

scenario: A company introduces a new productivity tool that automatically tracks active keyboard and mouse time for users (X). Managers report that tool users show higher 'productive hours' (Y) than non-users. However, non-users' productive hours are estimated from weekly self-reports, while users' hours come from automated tracking, which counts activity differently and may inflate or deflate compared to self-report.
claim: Using the productivity tool caused employees to be productive for more hours each week.
label: NO

X.name: Using the productivity tool with automated activity tracking

Z: Different measurement instruments (automated tracking vs self-report)
Different definitions of 'productive time' (activity vs meaningful work)
Gaming behavior (mouse jiggling) among tracked users

causal_structure: Exposure determines the measurement method for Y; automated metrics are not comparable to self-reports and can shift the measured outcome.
key_insight: When measurement differs across groups, differences can reflect instrumentation rather than true behavioral change.
hidden_timestamp: Were productive hours measured using the same definition and instrument for both tool users and non-users?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If both groups' productivity is measured using the same objective metric (or both use the same tracking rules) and users still improve, the tool could have a causal impact.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If users are measured by automated tracking while non-users are measured by self-report, the apparent difference may be a measurement artifact.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude the tool caused higher productivity because the outcome is measured differently for users and non-users.
gold_rationale: Differential measurement can create apparent treatment effects even when true productivity is unchanged.

scenario: A group of people joins a gym that provides a free wearable tracker to new members (X). After two months, the gym reports members increased their daily steps (Y). However, those who joined and activated the wearable have step counts captured automatically, while those who did not activate it self-report steps using rough estimates, making the measured increase potentially an artifact of improved tracking rather than real behavior change.
claim: Joining the gym caused members to take more steps per day.
label: NO

X.name: Joining the gym and activating the provided wearable tracker

Y.name: Daily step count over two months

Z: Automatic step capture vs self-estimated steps (instrument difference)
Wearable compliance and data missingness patterns
Baseline activity differences among those who activate trackers

causal_structure: Activation of tracking changes measurement accuracy and frequency, creating differential outcome measurement by exposure status.
key_insight: Better measurement can look like improvement even if true behavior is unchanged.
hidden_timestamp: Are steps measured identically (same wearable, same wear-time rules) for all members regardless of gym enrollment/activation status?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If everyone’s steps are measured with the same wearable and wear-time rules before and after enrollment, a true step increase could support causality.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only exposed participants have objective step tracking while others estimate steps, the apparent increase can be due to measurement differences.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude gym membership caused more steps because step measurement differs across groups and may reflect tracking differences rather than real change.
gold_rationale: Differential instrumentation by exposure status can generate spurious effects. This case demonstrates a clear causal reasoning pattern that requires careful analysis of the underlying mechanisms.

scenario: A company introduces a bonus tied to a simple metric: number of support tickets closed per day (X = exposure to the new incentive scheme). After the change, the average number of tickets closed (Y) increases, and leadership claims the incentive improved customer support outcomes. However, the incentive may change behavior in unintended ways: employees might close tickets faster without resolving issues, causing repeat tickets and worse customer satisfaction.
claim: Introducing the ticket-closure bonus improved customer support outcomes.
label: NO

Y.name: Customer support outcomes (quality of issue resolution)

Z: Shift in effort away from complex cases to easy-to-close cases
Customer satisfaction and repeat-contact rates not captured by closure count

causal_structure: X changes incentives and the pathway from effort to outcomes; improving the measured proxy (closures) may worsen the true outcome (resolution quality) via a different mechanism.
key_insight: Understanding the causal mechanism matters: optimizing a proxy can change behaviors along pathways that harm the real target outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Did the incentive increase true resolution quality (e.g., first-contact resolution, customer satisfaction), or only increase the closure count proxy?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If quality metrics (repeat-contact rate, satisfaction, audit scores) improve after introducing the bonus while controlling for volume, the incentive could improve outcomes.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only closure counts increased and quality worsened or was not measured, the incentive may have changed the mechanism toward superficial closures rather than better support.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude the bonus improved support outcomes because the incentive can change the mechanism, increasing closures while potentially reducing true resolution quality.
gold_rationale: Mechanism shifts and proxy optimization can produce misleading improvements in measured metrics without improving the underlying outcome.

scenario: A clinic gives patients a pamphlet encouraging daily weighing (X). After a month, patients show greater short-term weight fluctuations (Y) and the clinic claims the pamphlet made weight management worse. But daily weighing changes the measurement process and can reveal normal day-to-day variability that was previously unobserved, without changing true body composition.
claim: Encouraging daily weighing caused patients' weight to become more unstable.
label: NO

X.name: Encouragement to weigh daily (higher measurement frequency)

Z: Higher measurement frequency revealing natural fluctuation
Hydration and salt intake affecting daily weight readings
Scale calibration and measurement timing differences

causal_structure: X changes how often Y is observed; the apparent increase in variability may be due to the observation mechanism rather than true instability.
key_insight: Changing the measurement/observation mechanism can change observed outcomes even if the underlying state is unchanged.
hidden_timestamp: Was weight variability compared using the same measurement frequency and rules before and after the pamphlet intervention?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If both before and after periods use the same measurement frequency and protocol and variability still increases, the intervention might have affected behavior or physiology.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If variability appears larger only because measurements became daily (revealing normal fluctuation), the change reflects the observation mechanism, not a causal worsening.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude daily weighing made weight more unstable because increased measurement frequency can reveal normal fluctuations and inflate observed variability.
gold_rationale: Mechanism/measurement changes can alter observed patterns without changing underlying outcomes. This case demonstrates a clear causal reasoning pattern that requires careful analysis of the underlying mechanisms.

scenario: A teacher introduces timed quizzes (X) to increase learning efficiency. Students' quiz scores (Y) improve over the term, and the teacher claims timed quizzes cause better learning. However, timed quizzes may change study strategies (cramming for speed), shifting learning toward short-term recall that raises quiz scores but may reduce long-term retention, which is not measured.
claim: Timed quizzes caused students to learn better overall.
label: NO

Z: Shift toward test-taking strategies that boost short-term scores
Practice effects from repeated quizzes (familiarity with format)
Mismatch between measured quiz scores and true long-term understanding

causal_structure: X changes the pathway from studying to performance; improvements in proxy outcomes (quiz scores) may not translate to the intended outcome (retention).
key_insight: A mechanism that boosts a proxy metric can differ from the mechanism that improves the true target outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Is the outcome 'learning better' measured by long-term retention/transfer, or only by short-term timed quiz scores?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If students exposed to timed quizzes perform better on later untimed retention/transfer assessments compared to controls, the claim that learning improved becomes plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only timed quiz scores improved, the mechanism may reflect test-taking adaptation rather than better overall learning.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude timed quizzes improved overall learning because improved quiz scores could reflect a different mechanism (test-taking adaptation) than long-term understanding.
gold_rationale: Mechanism mismatch between proxy metrics and the target outcome can mislead causal claims. This case demonstrates a clear causal reasoning pattern that requires careful analysis of the underlying mechanisms.

scenario: A city launches a strict anti-littering campaign with fines (X). Initially, reported litter incidents (Y) fall. Months later, incidents rise above baseline and the city claims the campaign backfired by making people litter more. But increased reporting and enforcement attention after the campaign could increase recorded incidents even if true littering did not increase.
claim: The anti-littering campaign caused more littering (it backfired).
label: NO

X.name: Launching an anti-littering campaign with fines

Z: Increased enforcement and surveillance after campaign launch
Changes in citizen reporting behavior and hotline usage
Seasonal foot traffic changes affecting both true litter and detection

causal_structure: X can change both true behavior and detection/reporting; an apparent increase in Y may reflect heightened monitoring rather than a behavioral backfire.
key_insight: Apparent backfire effects can be artifacts of changed measurement, enforcement, or reporting after an intervention.
hidden_timestamp: Did true littering increase, or did only detection/reporting increase due to heightened enforcement after the campaign?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If independent audits using consistent measurement show more actual litter after the campaign compared to before and to comparable control areas, then a backfire effect is plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If recorded incidents rose because enforcement and reporting increased, the apparent backfire can be a measurement/reporting artifact rather than more littering.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude the campaign backfired because recorded incidents can rise simply due to increased enforcement and reporting after the campaign.
gold_rationale: Backfire claims require separating behavioral effects from changes in detection and reporting mechanisms.

scenario: A social media platform adds warning labels to disputed posts (X). After rollout, the platform observes that engagement with disputed content (Y) increases and claims the warnings backfired by attracting attention. However, the rollout also coincides with a major news event that increased overall interest in the topic, and the warning labels may have changed how posts are categorized as 'disputed,' affecting what is counted.
claim: Warning labels caused increased engagement with disputed posts (a backfire effect).
label: NO

X.name: Adding warning labels to disputed posts

Z: Concurrent news events increasing baseline interest and engagement
Changes in classification rules for what counts as 'disputed'

causal_structure: X coincides with external shocks and measurement redefinition; apparent increases can reflect reclassification or exogenous demand rather than a true backfire.
key_insight: To claim backfire, you must rule out concurrent events and measurement changes that can inflate the outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Were disputed posts and engagement measured consistently before and after labeling, and was there a comparable control period without the news shock?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If a randomized or staggered rollout shows labeled posts get higher engagement than similar unlabeled posts during the same time, a backfire effect is plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If engagement rose due to a major news event or because more posts were labeled 'disputed' after a definition change, the apparent backfire is not established.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude warning labels backfired because engagement changes may be driven by concurrent events or changes in what is counted as 'disputed.'
gold_rationale: Backfire inference is invalid when outcome measurement or external demand shifts coincide with the intervention.

scenario: A utility sends customers a letter comparing their electricity use to neighbors and encouraging conservation (X). Some customers then show higher electricity usage the next month (Y), and the utility claims the message backfired. But the higher usage month coincides with a heatwave, and customers who received the letter may differ by prior consumption tier and baseline seasonality patterns.
claim: The social-norm conservation letter caused customers to use more electricity (it backfired).
label: NO

X.name: Receiving a social-norm electricity conservation letter

Y.name: Electricity usage in the following month

Z: Heatwave and temperature differences affecting cooling demand
Baseline consumption tier targeted by the letter
Household occupancy changes during the month

causal_structure: Apparent increases after X can be driven by weather and targeting; backfire requires isolating the intervention effect from seasonality and selection.
key_insight: A post-intervention increase does not imply backfire without controlling for seasonality and targeting criteria.
hidden_timestamp: Were letter recipients randomly assigned and compared under the same weather conditions as non-recipients, with adjustment for baseline usage?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If customers were randomly assigned the letter and, controlling for temperature, recipients used more than controls, then a backfire effect is plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If recipients were targeted and a heatwave or occupancy changes drove usage, the increase cannot be attributed to a backfire from the letter.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude the letter backfired because higher usage could be explained by weather and targeted selection rather than the message causing increased consumption.
gold_rationale: Backfire claims require ruling out confounding and seasonality that can raise outcomes post-intervention.

scenario: People who start using a standing desk (X) report fewer headaches (Y). The company marketing the desk claims standing desks reduce headaches. But headaches may have prompted some people to switch to standing desks in the first place, meaning the outcome influenced the exposure.
claim: Using a standing desk causes fewer headaches.
label: NO

X.name: Starting to use a standing desk

Z: Ergonomic adjustments made at the same time (monitor height, chair)
Stress and sleep changes over the same period

causal_structure: Symptoms can trigger the intervention, reversing the presumed direction (Y → X), making X appear associated with lower Y due to symptom-driven adoption and regression.
key_insight: If the outcome influences exposure adoption, the association can be reverse causality rather than X causing Y.
hidden_timestamp: Did headache problems precede and motivate the decision to start using a standing desk?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If standing desk adoption was randomized or occurred for reasons unrelated to headaches (and headaches decreased afterward), a causal effect becomes plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If headaches drove the decision to adopt the standing desk, the observed association can be reverse causality rather than the desk reducing headaches.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude standing desks reduce headaches because headaches may have caused people to switch desks, reversing the causal direction.
gold_rationale: Reverse causation occurs when the outcome (or its risk) influences exposure uptake, biasing observational comparisons.

scenario: A bank offers a budgeting app (X). Customers who install it show lower overdraft fees over the next quarter (Y). The bank claims installing the app reduces overdrafts. However, customers may install the app because they recently experienced frequent overdrafts and want to improve, meaning prior overdraft problems drove installation.
claim: Installing the budgeting app causes customers to pay fewer overdraft fees.
label: NO

Y.name: Overdraft fees over the next quarter

Z: Recent overdraft problems motivating installation (reverse direction)
Concurrent changes like switching direct deposit timing or cutting spending
Seasonal income/expense variation across the quarter

causal_structure: High overdraft risk (or recent overdrafts) increases probability of adopting the app, so observed reductions can reflect reversion after a bad period rather than app effects.
key_insight: When people adopt tools in response to problems, it can look like the tool caused improvement even if the problem drove adoption.
hidden_timestamp: Were customers more likely to install the app immediately after experiencing overdrafts, compared to customers without recent overdrafts?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If installation was randomly offered/assigned or triggered for reasons unrelated to overdrafts and overdrafts still decline, the app could have a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If customers installed the app because of recent overdrafts, the association can reflect reverse causality and natural rebound rather than the app causing fewer fees.

wise_refusal: We can't conclude the app caused fewer overdraft fees because customers may install it in response to overdraft problems, reversing the causal direction.
gold_rationale: Reverse causality biases observational estimates when outcomes (or their risk) influence exposure uptake.

scenario: A person uses their credit card heavily (X), and then their credit score (Y) drops. They then reduce card usage, and later the score rises. They conclude: 'Using the card lowers my credit score, and lowering usage raises it.' But credit score affects available credit and borrowing behavior; a falling score can lead to changes in credit terms and payment behavior that then further affect the score, creating feedback.
claim: High credit card usage causes credit scores to drop in a simple one-way effect.
label: NO

Z: Credit score influencing credit limits and borrowing behavior
Payment timing changes triggered by score changes
Lender actions (limit reductions) in response to score/utilization

causal_structure: Credit utilization and credit score influence each other over time (X ↔ Y) through lender responses and consumer behavior, violating a simple one-way causal story.
key_insight: When variables influence each other over time, naïve causal claims that ignore feedback loops can be wrong.
hidden_timestamp: Is there a feedback loop where changes in credit score affect future utilization (via credit limits/behavior), which then affects the score again?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If utilization changes were externally imposed (e.g., randomized limit changes) and score changes followed without reverse effects, a one-way causal claim is more plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If score changes influence utilization and lender actions, the relationship involves feedback, and simple causal attribution from utilization to score is not justified.

wise_refusal: We can't treat this as a simple one-way causal effect because utilization and credit score can form a feedback loop through lender decisions and borrower behavior.
gold_rationale: Feedback systems require dynamic modeling; ignoring bidirectional influence can misattribute cause and effect.

scenario: A bank launches an app feature that nudges customers to enable automatic weekly transfers into savings (X). After two months, the bank reports that customers who enabled auto-transfers show higher average savings balances (Y) than those who did not. However, the app calculates 'savings balance' for auto-transfer users using end-of-day ledger balances that include pending transfers, while for non-users it reports only cleared available balances as of the statement cut-off. The reported difference may be partly due to how balances are computed rather than true differences in money saved.
claim: Enabling automatic weekly transfers caused customers to increase their savings over two months.
label: NO

X.name: Enabling automatic weekly transfers into savings

Y.name: Two-month change in reported savings balance

Z: Different balance definitions across groups (ledger including pending transfers vs cleared available balance)
Timing/statement cut-off effects that shift when deposits are counted
Baseline savings propensity and budgeting habits differing between adopters and non-adopters

causal_structure: Exposure status changes how Y is computed (ledger vs cleared balance and inclusion of pending items), creating differential measurement that can produce an apparent X→Y increase even if true savings behavior is similar.
key_insight: If outcome definitions differ by treatment status, observed gains can reflect accounting/measurement differences rather than a causal effect.
hidden_timestamp: Are savings balances computed the same way for auto-transfer users and non-users (same balance type, same cut-off time, same inclusion/exclusion of pending transactions)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If both groups' savings are measured using the same balance definition and timing (e.g., cleared balance at the same cut-off) and auto-transfer users still increase more, then enabling auto-transfers could have a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If auto-transfer users' balances include pending/ledger amounts while non-users' balances exclude them or use different cut-offs, the observed difference can be a measurement artifact rather than savings caused by the feature.

wise_refusal: We cannot attribute the higher reported savings to the auto-transfer feature because savings balances are computed differently across groups, which can create a spurious difference.
gold_rationale: Differential measurement of the outcome by exposure status (ledger vs cleared balance and timing differences) can inflate apparent savings for adopters without a true behavioral change.

scenario: A company offers an optional stress-management workshop and then compares stress outcomes between employees who choose to enroll versus those who do not. The analysis claims the workshop caused a reduction in stress because enrollees report lower stress afterward.
claim: If we assign employees to the stress-management workshop, their stress will decrease.
label: NO

Y.name: Employee stress level after the workshop period

Z: Self-selection into enrollment (motivated/less-stressed employees more likely to enroll)
Manager encouragement/support influencing both enrollment and stress

causal_structure: Because treatment is not randomly assigned and enrollment depends on stress-related traits (Z), comparing enrollees vs non-enrollees does not identify do(X) on Y.
key_insight: Opt-in comparisons conflate who chooses X with what X causes.
hidden_timestamp: Were employees randomly assigned to the workshop, or did they opt in (selection into X)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If enrollment is voluntary and related to stress determinants, the causal claim is not supported (NO).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If employees were randomized (or strong quasi-random assignment) and outcomes measured consistently, then the claim could be supported—but that is not described.

wise_refusal: No: the evidence compares employees who opted in versus those who did not. Self-selection into the workshop can drive the observed difference, so this does not establish a causal effect of assignment on stress.
gold_rationale: This is T1 selection: voluntary enrollment means treated and untreated groups can differ systematically on factors affecting stress, invalidating a causal claim about do(X).

scenario: A company tests a signing-bonus policy by offering bonuses to candidates for certain roles. Later, it compares job performance only among candidates who accepted offers, and concludes the bonus caused higher performance because bonus-offer acceptors perform better than non-bonus acceptors.
claim: If we assign candidates a signing bonus offer, their job performance will increase.
label: NO

Z: Conditioning on acceptance of the offer (collider/selection)
Candidate quality affects both acceptance and performance

causal_structure: Acceptance is influenced by both the bonus offer and candidate traits that also affect performance; restricting to acceptors conditions on a collider and can bias the estimated effect of X on Y.
key_insight: Analyzing only the people who “made it into” the dataset can manufacture an effect.
hidden_timestamp: Is performance compared only among those who accepted offers (conditioning on acceptance)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis restricts to acceptors and acceptance depends on both X and performance-related traits, the causal claim is not supported (NO).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If assignment is randomized and outcomes are tracked for all offered candidates regardless of acceptance (e.g., using intent-to-treat), then the causal claim could be evaluated—but that is not described.

wise_refusal: No: the analysis conditions on acceptance, which is influenced by the bonus offer and candidate characteristics. Conditioning on acceptance can bias the apparent effect, so the evidence does not support the causal claim.
gold_rationale: This is T3 collider/selection: restricting to acceptors conditions on a post-offer selection variable, invalidating causal inference about offering a bonus on performance.

scenario: A company evaluates a 6-week leadership training program. It defines the “trained” group as employees who completed all six weeks, and then measures promotions during the 6-week window and immediately after. Employees who were promoted or left the company before completing the program are counted in the “untrained” group.
claim: If we assign employees to the 6-week leadership training program, they will be promoted more often.
label: NO

X.name: Assignment to a 6-week leadership training program

Y.name: Promotion occurrence during/soon after the 6-week window

Z: Immortal time: must survive/remain employed long enough to be labeled 'trained'

trap.subtype_name: Treatment group defined by surviving long enough to complete

causal_structure: Defining treatment by completion creates an immortal period during which outcomes like leaving/promotion can be misattributed to the control group, biasing the apparent effect of X on Y.
key_insight: If you must survive to be counted as treated, treatment can look beneficial even if it isn’t.
hidden_timestamp: Is the treated group defined by completing the program (requiring employees to remain employed through the program duration)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If treatment status is defined by completion and outcomes during the completion window are handled asymmetrically, the causal claim is not supported (NO).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If employees are analyzed by intent-to-treat from assignment date (without completion-based reclassification) and timing is handled correctly, then the effect could be evaluated—but that is not described.

wise_refusal: No: this uses a completion-defined treated group, creating immortal time and reclassifying early outcomes into the control group. That bias can inflate the apparent promotion rate among 'trained' employees.
gold_rationale: This is T4 immortal time bias: treatment definition requires surviving to completion, which systematically excludes early events from the treated group and distorts causal inference.

subdomain: Performance feedback / regression to the mean
scenario: A manager assigns a productivity coaching session to the lowest-performing employees each month. The next month, those coached employees show improved performance scores on average. The manager concludes the coaching caused the improvement.
claim: If we assign low-performing employees to productivity coaching, their performance will improve.
label: NO

X.name: Assignment to productivity coaching (given to lowest performers)

Z: Regression to the mean from selecting extreme low performers

trap.subtype_name: Extreme-group selection followed by natural rebound

causal_structure: Selecting employees based on extreme low Y and then observing later Y tends to show improvement even without any intervention, so changes cannot be attributed to do(X).
key_insight: Extreme selection makes improvement likely even if nothing works.
hidden_timestamp: Were employees selected for coaching specifically because they had an unusually low score in the prior month?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If coaching is assigned to the lowest performers and improvement is judged by the next score, regression to the mean can explain the change, so the causal claim is not supported (NO).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If assignment is randomized among comparable employees (not based on extreme scores) and improvement persists beyond expected noise, then the claim could be supported—but that is not described.

wise_refusal: No: assigning coaching to the lowest performers sets up regression to the mean—scores often rise naturally after an unusually bad month. The observed improvement does not establish a causal effect of coaching.
gold_rationale: This is T5 regression: selecting on extreme outcomes and evaluating change afterward confounds natural variation with treatment effect.

scenario: A city increases funding for after-school programs in certain neighborhoods. At the neighborhood level, areas with larger funding increases later show larger reductions in youth crime rates. The city concludes that assigning a child to an after-school program reduces that child’s likelihood of committing a crime.
claim: If we assign a child to an after-school program, that child will be less likely to commit a crime.
label: NO

X.name: Assignment of an individual child to an after-school program

Y.name: Individual child’s likelihood of committing a crime

Z: Ecological mismatch: evidence is at neighborhood level, not individual level
Neighborhood changes correlated with funding (policing, demographics, economic shifts)

trap.subtype_name: Group-level association used to claim individual-level causality

causal_structure: Neighborhood-level changes do not identify individual-level causal effects; many neighborhood factors (Z) can drive aggregated trends, and individual assignment is not observed/identified.
key_insight: Group-level correlations don’t automatically translate to individual-level causal effects.
hidden_timestamp: Is the evidence based on neighborhood-level aggregates rather than individual children’s assignment and outcomes?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If only neighborhood-level funding and neighborhood crime rates are analyzed, the individual-level causal claim is not supported (NO).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If individual children were randomly assigned to programs and their outcomes tracked, the claim could be evaluated—but that is not described.

wise_refusal: No: the reported evidence is ecological (neighborhood-level). Inferring that assigning a specific child reduces that child’s crime risk is an ecological fallacy and is not supported by the described analysis.
gold_rationale: This is T6 ecological: aggregated associations cannot justify individual-level causal claims without individual-level identification.

scenario: A company “evaluates” standing desks by letting employees request them. Employees in roles with lighter physical demands request standing desks more often. Later, the company finds standing-desk users report less back pain and concludes assigning standing desks reduces back pain.
claim: If we assign employees to use standing desks, their back pain will decrease.
label: NO

Z: Job role/physical demands affecting both desk choice and back pain
Baseline back pain severity influencing requests

trap.subtype_name: Non-random assignment confounded by role and baseline pain

causal_structure: Because X is chosen/allocated based on role or symptoms (Z), comparing users vs non-users does not estimate the causal effect of assigning standing desks on back pain.
key_insight: When assignment isn’t random, pre-existing differences can masquerade as treatment effects.
hidden_timestamp: Were standing desks assigned randomly, or did employees self-select/request them in ways related to back pain and job role?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If employees self-select/request standing desks and those choices correlate with back pain determinants, the causal claim is not supported (NO).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If desks are randomized or quasi-randomly assigned and pain measured comparably, the claim could be supported—but that is not described.

wise_refusal: No: employees request standing desks, and roles/baseline pain likely affect both requesting and back pain. This confounding prevents concluding that assignment to standing desks causes lower pain.
gold_rationale: This is T7 confounder: non-random assignment confounded by role and baseline pain undermines causal identification of do(X) on Y.

scenario: A company provides healthy snacks in the office and evaluates whether this increases employee energy. In the analysis, it “adjusts for” whether employees ate the provided snacks during the day (a behavior influenced by providing snacks) and then compares energy levels between offices with and without the snack policy.
claim: If we assign an office to provide healthy snacks, employee energy will increase.
label: NO

Z: Post-treatment mediator: actually eating the provided snacks
Differential uptake affected by X and individual habits

trap.subtype_name: Adjusting for a post-treatment mediator / overcontrol bias

causal_structure: Conditioning on a mediator affected by X can block part of the causal pathway or introduce bias, so the adjusted comparison does not identify the total effect of do(X) on Y.
key_insight: Don’t “control away” the mechanism you’re trying to measure.
hidden_timestamp: Does the analysis adjust for a post-policy variable (snack consumption) that is itself affected by the policy?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the analysis controls for post-treatment snack consumption, it can bias the estimated effect and the causal claim is not supported (NO).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the goal is the total effect of providing snacks and the analysis avoids conditioning on mediators (or uses appropriate causal methods), the effect could be evaluated—but that is not described.

wise_refusal: No: the analysis adjusts for a post-treatment mediator (whether employees ate the snacks), which can bias or erase the causal effect pathway. This does not support a valid causal claim about the snack policy’s effect on energy.
gold_rationale: This is T9 confounder–mediator/overcontrol: conditioning on post-treatment variables affected by X breaks identification of the causal effect of do(X) on Y.

scenario: A company launches a productivity initiative and then uses manager-rated “initiative engagement” as a control in its model. Managers tend to rate employees as more engaged after they observe improvements in productivity. The company concludes assigning the initiative increases productivity because the coefficient on assignment is positive after controlling for engagement.
claim: If we assign employees to the productivity initiative, their productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Feedback: manager engagement ratings influenced by observed productivity

trap.subtype_name: A control variable is influenced by the outcome (Y → Z)

causal_structure: If Z (engagement rating) is affected by Y, conditioning on Z can induce bias and does not identify the causal effect of do(X) on Y.
key_insight: Controlling for something that is a consequence of the outcome can bias the estimated effect.
hidden_timestamp: Are the engagement ratings measured after (and influenced by) observed productivity changes?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If engagement ratings are influenced by productivity and used as controls, the causal claim is not supported (NO).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If engagement is measured pre-treatment (or not affected by Y) and assignment is otherwise valid, the effect could be evaluated—but that is not described.

wise_refusal: No: manager-rated engagement appears to be influenced by observed productivity, creating a feedback loop. Conditioning on a Y-influenced control can bias results, so this does not support the causal claim.
gold_rationale: This is T11 feedback: the analysis controls for a variable affected by Y, undermining causal identification of the effect of X.

scenario: A company introduces a new wellness program and simultaneously replaces an annual self-report health survey with a weekly app-based symptom check-in. After the change, average reported symptoms decrease, and leadership concludes assigning the wellness program reduced symptoms.
claim: If we assign employees to the wellness program, their health symptoms will decrease.
label: NO

Z: Measurement method change (annual survey vs weekly app check-ins)
Reporting incentives / social desirability differences across instruments

trap.subtype_name: Outcome measurement changes with the intervention

causal_structure: If Y is measured differently before vs after (or for treated vs untreated) due to X, changes in observed Y can reflect measurement artifacts (Z) rather than causal effects.
key_insight: Changing how you measure Y can look like changing Y.
hidden_timestamp: Did the outcome measurement method change at the same time as the wellness program rollout?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the program rollout coincides with a change in how symptoms are measured, the observed decrease may be a measurement artifact and the causal claim is not supported (NO).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If symptoms are measured consistently across time/groups with the same instrument and protocol, then the effect could be evaluated—but that is not described.

wise_refusal: No: the symptom metric changed when the program started (annual survey to weekly app check-ins). The apparent improvement may reflect measurement differences rather than a causal effect of the program.
gold_rationale: This is T13 measurement: outcome measurement changes with the intervention, confounding the observed trend with instrumentation effects.

scenario: A company assigns a new incentive plan that rewards employees based on the number of customer calls logged per day. After the change, call logs increase sharply, and leadership claims the incentive caused higher customer satisfaction. However, satisfaction is not measured; only call-count logs are.
claim: If we assign the call-count incentive plan, customer satisfaction will increase.
label: NO

X.name: Assignment to incentive plan rewarding call-count logs

Z: Goodhart: call-count becomes a target and can be gamed
Call quantity may substitute for call quality

trap.subtype_name: Optimizing a proxy metric breaks its link to the true goal

causal_structure: X directly changes the logging/proxy behavior and can decouple the proxy from the true objective Y; observing more proxy activity does not establish improved satisfaction.
key_insight: When a measure becomes a target, it stops being a good measure.
hidden_timestamp: Is the evidence only that the proxy metric (call-count logs) increased, without direct measurement of satisfaction or quality?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the incentive targets a proxy that can be gamed and Y is not directly measured, the causal claim about satisfaction is not supported (NO).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If satisfaction is directly measured and quality is maintained (e.g., audits show no gaming) with a valid design, the effect could be evaluated—but that is not described.

wise_refusal: No: the intervention incentivizes a proxy (call-count logs) that can be gamed, and the evidence is only an increase in that proxy, not in customer satisfaction. This is a Goodhart trap, so the causal claim is not supported.
gold_rationale: This is T16 Goodhart: optimizing a proxy metric can inflate the proxy without improving the true goal, so observed proxy gains do not justify a causal claim about customer satisfaction.

scenario: A company compares employees who choose to work from home (WFH) three days a week to employees who choose to work in the office full time. The WFH group shows higher average weekly output. Employees self-select into WFH based on their preferences and job roles, and no random assignment or identification strategy is described.
claim: If the company allows employees to work from home three days per week, their weekly output will increase.
label: NO

X.name: Allowing/choosing WFH three days per week (opt-in)

Z: Job role suitability for remote work
Manager trust and assignment of projects

causal_structure: Z influences both opting into WFH (X) and output (Y). Because employees self-select, the observed WFH–output difference can be driven by selection rather than a causal effect of the policy.
key_insight: Opt-in groups are not comparable; selection can explain the observed difference.
hidden_timestamp: Did employees self-select into WFH (rather than being randomly assigned), and could role/motivation differences explain output?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If employees were randomly assigned to WFH versus office (or a credible identification strategy removed selection), a higher output under WFH would support the claim (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If WFH is opt-in and role/motivation differences drive both WFH choice and output, the observed difference does not support the causal claim (NO).

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude that allowing WFH increases output because employees opt into WFH based on role and preferences that also affect productivity; the observed association is consistent with selection rather than causation.
gold_rationale: T1 opt-in selection: self-selection into treatment creates non-comparable groups, so the causal effect of allowing WFH is not identified by this comparison.

scenario: A dieting app reports that among users who continue logging meals for at least 90 consecutive days, average weight decreases substantially over the 90-day period. The report excludes users who stop logging earlier and does not describe whether early dropouts gained weight or were less motivated.
claim: If people use the dieting app for 90 days, it will cause them to lose weight over that period.
label: NO

X.name: Using the dieting app for 90 consecutive days (stayers)

Z: Selection on persistence (only consistent loggers included)
Motivation / baseline discipline affecting both persistence and weight loss

causal_structure: Conditioning on staying/logging for 90 days selects a subgroup likely different in motivation and outcomes; the observed weight loss among stayers may not reflect the app’s causal effect for typical users.
key_insight: Stayer-only summaries can be driven by who sticks with the program, not what the program does.
hidden_timestamp: Is the reported weight loss computed only among users who stayed/logged for 90 days (excluding dropouts)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If both stayers and dropouts were included (or dropout were properly modeled) and app use still predicted weight loss, the claim could be evaluated (AMBIGUOUS given that information is missing).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis includes only 90-day stayers, survivorship bias undermines causal inference, so the claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No. The app’s report is restricted to users who stayed for 90 days; excluding dropouts can inflate apparent success. Without accounting for survivorship and motivation differences, the causal claim is not supported.
gold_rationale: T2 survivorship: restricting to persistent users biases the estimate and does not identify the causal effect for the broader population of app users.

scenario: Employees are assigned to either attend a time-management workshop or not. In the analysis, the company restricts attention to employees who complied with their assignment (i.e., only those assigned to attend who actually attended, and only those assigned not to attend who indeed did not attend). The company then compares productivity between these restricted groups and concludes the workshop increased productivity.
claim: If the company assigns employees to the time-management workshop, their productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Compliance with assignment (post-assignment behavior influenced by motivation/constraints)

causal_structure: Compliance is affected by assignment (X) and also by factors like motivation and workload that influence productivity (Y). Conditioning on compliance can open a collider path and bias the estimated effect of assignment on productivity.
key_insight: Conditioning on a post-treatment variable (compliance) can create bias even when assignment is meaningful.
hidden_timestamp: Did the analysis condition on compliance (restricting to those who followed their assignment), a post-assignment variable related to motivation?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If productivity were compared by assignment in the full sample (without conditioning on compliance), assignment-based differences could support the claim (YES if higher under assignment).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the analysis restricts to compliers/non-compliers (conditioning on compliance), collider bias can distort the relationship, so the claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No. The analysis conditions on compliance, which is influenced by assignment and by motivation/constraints related to productivity. Conditioning on compliance can induce collider bias, so the reported comparison does not justify the causal claim.
gold_rationale: T3 collider (conditioning on compliance): restricting to compliers breaks causal identification and can produce a biased estimate of the workshop’s effect.

scenario: A clinic study defines patients as 'treated' if they filled at least three prescription refills within the first 60 days after diagnosis. The study then compares 90-day hospitalization rates between 'treated' and 'untreated' patients and finds lower hospitalization among the treated group. Patients must remain alive and not be hospitalized early to accumulate three refills, but this 'immortal' period is not accounted for.
claim: If patients take the medication, their 90-day hospitalization risk will decrease.
label: NO

X.name: Classified as treated by meeting a refill-based definition (≥3 refills in 60 days)

Z: Immortal time: needing to remain event-free long enough to be labeled treated

causal_structure: Treatment classification requires surviving and avoiding early hospitalization during the refill-accumulation window. This immortal time mechanically lowers observed event rates in the treated group, biasing the comparison.
key_insight: Defining treatment using future information creates an 'immortal' window that guarantees survival, producing spurious benefit.
hidden_timestamp: Is treatment defined using future refills such that patients must remain event-free long enough to be classified as treated (immortal time)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If treatment start time were aligned properly (time-varying exposure with correct risk sets), a lower hospitalization rate could support a protective effect (YES, conditional on proper modeling).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If treatment is defined by future refills creating immortal time, the observed benefit can be purely mechanical, so the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No. Because treatment is defined by accumulating refills over time, patients must survive and avoid early hospitalization to be labeled treated. This immortal time biases the comparison and can create a false protective effect.
gold_rationale: T4 immortal time: treatment classification uses future survival/event-free time, invalidating the causal conclusion from the reported treated-vs-untreated comparison.

subdomain: Customer service coaching / regression to mean
scenario: A call center introduces a new coaching script and applies it only to agents who had an unusually low customer satisfaction (CSAT) score in the previous month. In the next month, the coached agents’ average CSAT increases. No comparison group of similarly low-CSAT agents without the script is provided, and the selection threshold targets extreme low scores.
claim: If the call center gives agents the new coaching script, their CSAT will improve.
label: NO

X.name: Receiving the coaching script (assigned because prior CSAT was extremely low)

Z: Regression to the mean from an extreme prior-month CSAT

causal_structure: Selecting agents based on an extreme low prior outcome creates expected rebound toward typical performance even without intervention; the post-intervention improvement can reflect regression to the mean rather than X -> Y.
key_insight: Extreme outcomes tend to move closer to average on re-measurement even without treatment.
hidden_timestamp: Were agents selected for the script specifically because they had an unusually low CSAT month (an extreme prior value)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If similarly low-CSAT agents were randomly split into script vs no-script and only the script group improved, that would support a causal effect (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only extreme low-CSAT agents received the script and then improved, the rebound can be regression to the mean, so the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No. The script was given only to agents selected for an unusually low CSAT month, and their scores would typically rebound toward average even without any change. Without a proper comparison, the improvement does not support a causal effect of the script.
gold_rationale: T5 regression to the mean: selecting on an extreme prior outcome makes subsequent improvement expected even absent treatment, so the causal claim is not identified.

scenario: A report compares neighborhoods and finds that neighborhoods with higher average weekly gym attendance also have lower average obesity rates. The report concludes that individuals who attend the gym more often are less likely to be obese. The report provides only neighborhood-level averages and no individual-level link between a person’s gym attendance and their obesity status.
claim: If a person attends the gym more often, it will reduce their chance of obesity.
label: NO

Z: Only aggregate neighborhood-level averages are observed (no individual-level data)

causal_structure: The evidence is at the group (neighborhood) level while the claim is at the individual level. Group-level correlations do not identify individual-level causal effects and can be driven by compositional differences.
key_insight: You cannot infer an individual causal effect from aggregate correlations.
hidden_timestamp: Is the evidence only neighborhood-level averages while the claim is about individual people (no individual-level linkage)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If individual-level data showed that within comparable people higher gym attendance predicts lower obesity, the claim could be evaluated (AMBIGUOUS here because such data are absent).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only neighborhood-level averages are available, the individual-level causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No. The report uses neighborhood-level averages but makes an individual-level causal claim. This ecological inference is invalid without individual-level data linking gym attendance to obesity outcomes.
gold_rationale: T6 ecological: aggregate associations do not identify individual-level causal effects, so the evidence described does not support the claim.

scenario: An office study compares employees who drink coffee in the morning to employees who do not and finds that coffee drinkers complete more tasks before noon. The study does not adjust for baseline sleep or role demands, and coffee use is not randomized.
claim: If employees drink coffee in the morning, their pre-noon task completion will increase.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z can influence both coffee consumption (X) and morning productivity (Y). Without randomization or adequate adjustment, the observed association can be confounded and does not identify the causal effect.
key_insight: A common cause (sleep, workload) can make coffee drinkers look more productive even if coffee has no causal effect.
hidden_timestamp: Were coffee drinkers different in baseline sleep or workload in ways that affect both coffee use and morning productivity?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If coffee use were randomized (or strong adjustment made treated/untreated comparable) and task completion increased, the claim could be supported (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If sleep/workload confounds coffee use and productivity and is not controlled, the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No. Coffee drinking is not randomized and baseline sleep or workload can influence both coffee use and pre-noon productivity. Without controlling for confounding, the observed association does not support the causal claim.
gold_rationale: T7 confounder: common-cause confounding means the causal effect of coffee is not identified from this observational comparison.

scenario: A company rolls out a new task-tracking tool and compares overall productivity before and after adoption. Overall, users of the tool appear to have higher productivity than non-users. However, when productivity is analyzed within each team, tool users in every team have slightly lower productivity than non-users in that same team. Teams differ in baseline productivity, and high-performing teams adopt the tool at higher rates.
claim: If employees use the new task-tracking tool, their productivity will increase.
label: NO

Z: Team (baseline productivity differs; adoption rates differ by team)

causal_structure: Z (team) affects both adoption (X) and productivity (Y). Aggregating across teams reverses the within-team relationship, making the overall comparison misleading for a causal claim.
key_insight: If every subgroup shows the opposite pattern, the aggregate association is a Simpson’s paradox trap.
hidden_timestamp: Does the tool–productivity relationship reverse when stratifying by team (within-team lower productivity for tool users)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the claim were only about the aggregate descriptive average, it could describe the combined data but would not identify causality (AMBIGUOUS for a causal claim).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the intended causal claim is about comparable employees within teams, the within-team pattern contradicts the claim, so it is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No. This is Simpson’s paradox: overall tool users look more productive, but within every team tool users are less productive. The aggregate comparison is misleading and does not support a causal productivity increase.
gold_rationale: T8 Simpson’s: aggregation across teams with different baselines and adoption rates produces a reversal, so the causal claim is not supported by the described evidence.

scenario: A company evaluates whether assigning employees to a lunchtime walking program (X) reduces end-of-day fatigue (Y). In the analysis, they adjust for the number of steps recorded during lunch (a post-assignment variable directly affected by the program). After adjusting for steps, they find little difference in fatigue and conclude the program does not reduce fatigue.
claim: If employees are assigned to the lunchtime walking program, their end-of-day fatigue will decrease.
label: NO

Z: Lunch-step count (post-treatment mediator affected by assignment)

causal_structure: Steps are downstream of assignment and plausibly mediate fatigue reduction. Adjusting for a mediator removes part of the effect and can induce bias; the adjusted comparison does not estimate the total causal effect of assignment on fatigue.
key_insight: Controlling for a post-treatment mediator answers a different question and can erase the effect you’re trying to estimate.
hidden_timestamp: Did the analysis control for a post-assignment variable (steps) that lies on the causal pathway from the walking program to fatigue?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the goal is the total effect of assignment on fatigue, then adjusting for steps is inappropriate and the conclusion does not follow (NO).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the goal were a controlled direct effect holding steps fixed (and that estimand were explicitly defined), the result could be interpreted differently (AMBIGUOUS without a clear estimand and assumptions).

wise_refusal: No. The analysis adjusts for step count, which is affected by the walking program and likely mediates fatigue reduction. This post-treatment adjustment does not estimate the program’s total causal effect and can mask it.
gold_rationale: T9 post-treatment mediator adjustment: controlling for a mediator changes the estimand and can invalidate the causal conclusion about the total effect of the program.

scenario: Employees are offered stress coaching only after their manager reports a spike in missed deadlines. After coaching begins, their missed deadlines decrease over the next month. The company concludes that coaching caused the improvement, but coaching was targeted to employees right after an unusually bad month.
claim: If employees receive stress coaching, their missed deadlines will decrease.
label: NO

X.name: Receiving stress coaching (triggered by a recent spike in missed deadlines)

Y.name: Number of missed deadlines in the following month

Z: Reactive assignment based on recent poor performance (spike)

causal_structure: Coaching is assigned in response to a spike in the outcome (or related early warning). A natural rebound after a bad month can occur without coaching; targeting based on worsening can create an apparent improvement unrelated to treatment.
key_insight: When treatment is triggered by a worsening outcome, improvement afterward can reflect timing/selection rather than causality.
hidden_timestamp: Was coaching initiated specifically after a spike in missed deadlines (i.e., treatment assignment was reactive to the outcome)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If coaching were assigned independently of recent deadline performance (or with a proper comparison group), a subsequent reduction could support the claim (YES).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If coaching is triggered by an unusually bad month, the post-coaching improvement can be a rebound, so the causal claim is not supported (NO).

wise_refusal: No. Coaching was assigned reactively after a spike in missed deadlines, so the later improvement may reflect a rebound from an unusually bad month rather than a causal effect of coaching.
gold_rationale: T10 reactive assignment: treatment is triggered by worsening outcomes, which can create spurious pre/post improvements unrelated to the causal effect.
